150379529.review:
I've played this in the Nexon era and the game is considerably better now than then. I think the mixed reviews are unwarranted and seem mainly tied to issues with the steam version of the game but i personally haven't had any beyond the clunky process of purchasing premium currency.
[b]The game is good but it's definitely not for everyone.[/b] Some things to keep in mind.

1. It is NOT p2w but rather pay to speed up progress.

2. At the moment, progression at max level is designed around a person being able to solo everything without a group minus a couple of raids but those are optional. You can still play this with friends, it's just not as common as it once was to party up.

3. It revolves around creating multiple characters and have one character to feed all your resources into. After that, you move on to the next. You get rewarded the more alts you have.

4. The real game starts at level 110, this also means that all content released focuses on the max level. Everything up until that point follows the basic formula of (Complete Dungeon -> Level up -> Move to next area). It works though because all the classes are varied and are quite unique in their Playstyles.

5. At Max level, there is a "Fame" system which determines how strong your character is and what dungeons you can access. Building up this fame is pretty easy until you reach around 33k-35k, at that point you're time gated for progress. Generally that's when I create another character or progress on another one until the next week when I can do more raids. The game at this point opens up and can become confusing without some sort of guidance so I'd recommend checking out the 80% DFO Discord or dfo.gg

6. The fatigue point system has been criticized but the game is balanced around it. Most importantly farming gold, at end-game, without the FP system you would easily completely ruin the economy with how much people can blitz through dungeons and make money. It keeps that in check and allows newer players to keep up. There is additionally NEO Premium which increases you fatigue limit quite a bit.

7. Inflation hasn't seem to be an issue, generally prices have remained mostly the same from what i can tell. Rare Avatar pieces go for 30m, normal avatar sets go for 10m. Depends on supply and demand.

8. The game has a rather small population and finding guides can be difficult, I'd recommend checking out the "80% DFO" discord or dfo.gg for an encyclopedia. 

So, TLDR Key points
 - Fatigue Point System
 - Pay to Progress Faster
 - Small community
 - Engaging Beat-em-up Gameplay
 - Focus on making alts to fund mains

149671126.review:
[h1] Honest Review - Dungeon Fighter Online [/h1]

	I spent [b] $45,000 [/b] on a relentless journey into the heart of darkness with Dungeon Fighter Online (DFO), a 2D beat-em-up game that has garnered both fervent enthusiasts and critical skeptics, beckons you with its complex tapestry. With a staggering array of over 15 characters and 50 diverse subclasses spread across them, you'll traverse a world where the convergence of combat and fantasy offers both moments of exhilaration and doubt. The game's journey, originally orchestrated by Nexon in 2010 for North American players, underwent further evolution under Neople's guidance in 2014, garnering praise and reservations alike. Echoing the echoes of timeless classics such as "Golden Axe" and "Double Dragon," DFO attempts to interweave the spirit of vintage side-scrolling action with a contemporary twist, leaving players both enchanted and uncertain. As you unsheathe your blades and conjure your spells, a tale unfolds that challenges you to embrace the essence of a fighter, navigating the depths of the dungeon amidst a sea of mixed opinions.
	
	This game effortlessly channels the exhilarating essence of classic beat-em-up games, immersing players in a world of visceral combat and relentless action. Even the mechanics pay homage to the genre's roots, with controls that demand precision and strategy. Yet, as you navigate through the game's stages, an intriguing conflict unfolds. First, we have the gameplay structure that even though it resembles the beat-em-up style, the challenge curve takes a somewhat unexpected turn. Early on, the foes you face seem almost unresponsive and random, that they are often neglecting a focused assault on your character which makes for the lack of punishing difficulty that characterized old-school beat-em-up titles. Then, there are the controls, while reminiscent of their predecessors, exhibit a hint of lag, which can hinder the seamless execution of combos and precise movement. Alongside the controls, it follows with the skills, though imbued with a sense of power, at times feel disjointed, struggling to find a harmonious rhythm when combined.  With these issues combined, it leads to an unchallenged level up system for dungeons to be swept with minimal effort; an absence in a once-familiar difficulty system to meet your combat prowess; a rare fatigue system not seen in more recent games that raises questions in the late-game challenge; and a redundant loot system that leaves dungeons' post victory item bonuses somewhat disconnected from the experience. With this in mind, DFO offers a unique perspective that treads a fine line between nostalgia and modernity, while leaving room for evolution.
	
	As DFO masterfully evokes the nostalgia of 90's 2D beat-em-up classics through its pixel art graphics, it weaves a rich tapestry of visuals that pays homage to the genre's golden age with a price. Luckily, the visual style extends beyond mere aesthetics, as each character is brought to life with meticulously crafted illustrations that unveil a unique story and exude distinctive personality and flair. However, while the skills themselves are a visual feast, there's room for growth in terms of character animations, particularly in their death poses and during pivotal story cutscenes. With a slight positive note in design, sound effects (SFX) and soundtrack blends a varied chord, blending seamlessly in some scenes while leaving a jarred dissonance in others. There are also glitches found in the SFX and BGM to either amplify in volume or even echo after boss battles and cutscenes. In essence, the visuals and audial components come together to create an intricate tapestry that charts a mixed course of its own.
	
	DFO's storyline unfortunately is the highest form of disappointment as it struggles to hold players in its narrative grasp. The tale occasionally stumbles, marked by intermittent breaks, that are particularly evident in the initial stages of the game. These pauses prompt a sense of disconnection, amplified by timeline points that sometimes raise questions. Yet, as the story unfolds, the desire to hit the spacebar and forgo the narrative altogether creeps in. Although the plot eventually weaves its threads into a semblance of coherence, the overarching feeling is one of sidelining and fragmentation. The protagonist's backstory, outlined in the opening, fails to undergo meaningful development, leaving them stagnant throughout the adventure. This leads the character's role within the story to be reduced to a mere errand-runner, devoid of personal purpose or motivation. Alongside, character interactions are punctuated by sporadic lines that, while well-executed, provide only a modest layer to the gameplay experience. It ends up preventing any attachment to the characters or immersion in the plot. Regrettably, the narration lacks emotional resonance, character growth remains stunted, and pacing falters, resulting in an overall narrative experience that falls disappointingly short of its potential.
	
	DFO is strategically crafted for a diverse audience, catering to teens and adults with a mosaic of opinions who seek a blend of nostalgia and contemporary gameplay. Amidst honest evaluations, echoes of trolling can be found in reviews, underscoring the passionate yet contentious dialogue surrounding the game. Critics recount unfavorable encounters with the Steam edition, recounting instances where false bot flags led to bans and frustrating interactions with Neople's customer service. There have also been tales of bans tied to in-game currency purchases, prompting some to advocate for playing directly from the official site. This also ties with the pay-to-win system to add a layer of complexity, with some arguing this model's prevalence. Yet, positive perspectives remain steadfast, celebrating engaging gameplay, captivating art, and an intriguing storyline.  Be as it may, the community dynamics mirror this diversity, with factions that cater to elite players, offering meticulous guides and guilds for character building and raids, while others feel marginalized. Contrasting these viewpoints, voices hail the welcoming and supportive nature of communities on Discord, Reddit, and Wiki sites. As the game continue to hold what is true, the recent patch, introducing the Muse/Traveler character, complete with novel skills, art, and playstyle, reignites optimism for the game's future, hoping to lure new players into the ever-evolving world of Dungeon Fighter Online.
	
	In conclusion, DFO presents itself as a neutral experience, showcasing a spectrum of strengths and weaknesses that shape its gaming identity to cater to a broad audience. The game's visual aesthetics and nostalgic gameplay elements evoke fond memories of classic titles, yet its storyline falls short of captivating players, leaving a void for those who value narrative engagement. While the allure of end-game content is present, the sense of accomplishment it provides could be more pronounced. For enthusiasts of the genre, the active and visually appealing gameplay will resonate, even though the game's overall potential could be further realized through improvements. As a timeless title, Dungeon Fighter Online has a foundation that could be elevated with enhancements, particularly by introducing separate difficulty levels for veterans and elevating its storyline and character development. Until then, while the game offers certain attractions, it may not wholly satisfy those seeking a deeply immersive narrative experience.
	
[h2] Final Score [/h2]	
	Mechanics : 7/10
	Story : 3/10
	Gameplay : 6/10
	Music : 4/10
	Art : 9/10
	
	[h3] Overall Score : 6/10 [/h3]

This is my first review that I took some time to write, so please feel free to give some input.

149330426.review:
El juego es muy entretenido, tiene jefes (la mayor parte del contenido, el cual desbloqueas al final del juego. antes del nivel 99, todo es tutorial) cuyas mecánicas realmente los hacen difíciles y no son el clásico caso de "dificil por estadísticas" o cosas similares, el único problema que tengo con este juego es que, si quieres progresar bien, tienes que meterle demasiadas horas para poder conseguir la moneda del juego y comprar paquetes, cuyos muchas veces vienen con títulos (un tipo de equipamiento en el juego que te aumenta mucho el daño, etc), mascotas y este tipo de cosas, convirtiéndose en minimax un un tanto excesivo. Aún así, recomiendo el juego porque de verdad, incluso aunque desees jugar unicamente con un personaje y decidas avanzar lento (que esta es  otra de las problemáticas, el conseguir equipamiento es muy limitado por tiempo, únicamente consiguiente pocos materiales semanalmente, por ejemplo) a no ser que crees otros personajes y, aparte, que sean capaces de enfrentarse al contenido de "end-game", podrás disfrutar de las dinámicas y peleas contra dicho contenido, que en mi opinión, es el punto clave para divertirse en este juego. 
Aveces suelen meter eventos para adelantar este "farmeo", pero igualmente, yo llegué al punto de tener que parar debido al tiempo que me estaba consumiendo, pese a eso, la experiencia que tuve en el juego no fue nada mala.

Pay to win grind fest with that dingy Korean flavor. Ain't hard to find reviews of auto bans, and a handful suggests downloading from their website. FORGET playing it period. Common complaints are the toxicity, the fatigue points (energy system), and 4-6 month long grinds (if done competently) before you can even touch the actual multiplayer aspect of this Korean MMO (don't forget its toxicity). The only reason to boot it up would be to test out the 60+ classes that you can check out on youtube for a general gist of the action that you'll never actually get to play, especially with other players. Instead you'll slog through the glorified tutorial that is the ACTUAL GAME until you finally reach level cap a week later, or if there's an event, maybe an hour later. a VERY BORING hour. Then say hello to your first endgame raid where everybody hates your guts, will pester you to make a new character if it ain't viable for the meta, will hate your guts some more, will demand you start abiding to the pay to win guidelines aka the Korean bible, and will likely be grown men playing as a sadistic magical loli or sword waifu, all while flaunting their cash or sad grind obsession throughout. This is all nothing but a grind simulator with a mindless, button mashing mini-game (the actual gameplay) tacked in. Plus, the devs are jackasses. 

Just spend your p2w money on Final Fantasy 14 or the latest Monster Hunter, or your time investment on actual f2p games like Genshin or whatever. Where devs are actually decent and communities are far less toxic.

144369087.review:
Steam Version Currently Unplayable.

Now this might not apply to all steam users, if not good for you idrc

A large number of users that play this game through the steam version are having their experience slighted, by a pop-up the occurs in-game, locking you out of your control and prompting for a "captcha" before unlocking and resuming gameplay. This can occur as frequently as 2-6 times in 1 dungeon. 

There has been some discussion as we all tried to figure out what the issue is, each of us being told by support that it is likely caused on our end by a macro or VPN. 

Naturally, that is the liability-secure answer, but it is quite clear to me that it is strictly a steam-version issue, and I don't appreciate the run-around they are giving us. 

Obviously I can't assign intent with so little information, but with DFO recently being published on the Epic client, this does make me wonder aloud if this was a decision, or a known issue that they intentionally don't address, 

Imo it's a bad business move by Neople either way. Over the course of the decade or so I've played this through Neople (also played through Nexon back in the day), I've easily spent atleast a grand on this game. If they successfully get me to switch to playing through their own launcher or through the epic client, they chance they get a dime out of me going forward is 0, but if they let me continue to play normally through steam, the chance I spend more money is >0. Idk the deal/ratio they get from valve on this, but a X% of something > 100% of nothing 

Also I probably wouldn't have ever re-downloaded this game had I not seen it on my Steam recommendations, so I think Valve getting a cut of that pie is fair.

136979646.review:
As someone who played the NA version of the game when it launched in 2010 and was super disappointed after all the hype, being able to come back and play an actually enjoyable version of the game now and quickly proceed to level 110 (current cap) and experience the end game content is definitely worth it. The game is also really good at walking through where you need to go next to progress, for late 2000s MMO standards at least. By far the worst part is the download experience; the launcher appears to only be able to download a single file at a time, and there's well over 100,000 files since they're not properly archived, which means you're effectively capping out at 8 MB/s or so. Again, in 2010 that was probably fine because few people had internet much faster than that, but for the love of God Nexon please fix this. Based on the achievement stats where less than 25% of people are getting the achievements that you get within the first 20 minutes of actual gameplay, I imagine a good amount of people who open the launcher are giving up before the download even finishes.

Also, for some reason the cash shop has very few cosmetic outfits. Like I want to give Nexon some money but there's only like 3 pages of outfits and none are good

130319799.review:
The gameplay loop of this MMO is, in my opinion, easily the best that exists on the market (which is crazy because this game is somewhere close to 20 years old). The pixel art style is also second-to-none, with very flashy abilities and overall an extremely charming aesthetic. 

However, it's a Korean MMO; that naturally means that you can expect a grind. However, the grind in DFO is ridiculous. Leveling to max level is a glorified tutorial, which is fine because it only takes a few days, but once you're at max, the *real* grind begins. As a complete noob, you can expect to spend anywhere from 4-6 months of *daily playing* to get a character endgame ready, and that may not even be for the most current content depending on RNG. The grind isn't ridiculous purely because of the fatigue system, which only allows you to enter a certain amount of dungeons per day (this system is in place to encourage creating many alts, which is fine for veteran players, but for a new player it will cause frustration). I have nearly 500 hours in the game and I'm nowhere near being able to do the latest endgame content *on my main,* let alone my alts (granted, I only play 2-3 times a year in big months-long binges, but that seems irrelevant considering the time investment over multiple years). 

If you're looking for an MMO to invest time into, this is absolutely the one, due to its frankly perfect combat and general gameplay loop. However, you're going to struggle for months as a noobie with catching up to the current content, as well as a serious case of system bloat. Seriously, the system bloat can't be understated, it's a nearly 20 year old Korean MMO after all; the number of convoluted systems for improving your gear/damage is absurd. But if you can tolerate that stuff, there's a truly fun, engaging, and overall charming game underneath it all.

Lastly, if you're considering playing DFO, play it from the client from Neople, not through Steam; the Steam client is known to cause illegitimate bans. That has been the case for years; either Neople doesn't care about the Steam client because nobody plays it, or they literally don't know how to fix the problem. In any case, definitely play through the official client from Neople.

128569255.review:
It's a fun game and come in out to pop up to play and sink hours into it. I have been playing this game since its release into U.S territory. A lot of the reviews seem to stem from player burnout or a few YIKES issues which is fine and understood but for myself personally it is a great game for what it is which is an online beatem dungeon crawler. 

There isn't anything close to DFO other then a few rogues or beatem ups that do not have save progress for gear and items which this game inherently has. 

I do not feel left behind when I log in. As a veteran player -- there are opportunities to come back and be fleshed out with weapon and armor crate supplies that may help you with your adventures and game progress.  

Of course they're not going to give you the endgame of endgame gears but that would be boring. And I would highly consider playing something else if that is what you are looking for.  Or reconsider just to STOP PLAYING MMOS. 

Of course there are going to be players who are solid and not solid for dungeons or game play. And that is not on the game but the player base in any mmo franchise. Technically a lot of these issues stem from STEAM CLIENT which is funny cause I do not have a problem with it so I am going to assume a lot of this is not user-friendly for non-tech. I do agree there are less issues directly from DFO Global site. 

I have probably played this more then the 3k hours sinked in on my profile. Still have a great work life balance and play other games and switch off.  I haven't logged in a few months but I would highly suggest if you haven't and can look past the gripes that are sort of lingered on this page; that it is a pretty solid gem.  DFO is a solid game but the Global Community has players running out the door. This is pretty standard. Any player that has played DFO for 6 years or longer would this to be true.

128508238.review:
Pay to win is so deeply embedded into this game it's stunning. The game will not even allow you to use the in-game shop until you spend $150 up front. Newcomers have to go and use the shitty web store that's specifically missing the cheapest avatars.

Character cosmetic 'avatars' are the only way to change your default appearance, if you don't pay; your 110 character will look identical to level 1.

These avatars give stat boosts and bonus EXP increase, if you don't have deep pockets you'll get kicked out of group content for lacking significant damage or buff enhancements.

Avatars are also character bound and class specific. New cosmetic sets don't even include outfits for the latest classes.

Cosmetics aside the game will amaze you with all its time gated content, level gated content, fame gated content, and my favorite; material gated content.

High end skills in DFO not only cost mana and go on cooldown when used, they also chew your crafting material, clear cube fragment, and if you run out of those your character can only use basic attacks and be locked out of the class-defining skills. I ran out around level 102 while trying to level some alts.

128192966.review:
I've played this game since it came out under Nexon back in the day, so give or take 12 years ago. It previously closed in 2013 after being absolutely mishandled by the company and re-released under the parent company Neople in 2015. 

As a veteran player, I highly recommend trying this game out at least once. It has fantastic visuals, an awesome soundtrack, fun dungeons, and overall very fun gameplay. The game is very old, so the UI is slightly clunky but once you move past that it's a tremendously fun time, and the game itself really is genuinely not THAT p2w as some people might say. 

The leveling experience is extremely fun and in upcoming updates from the time of this post they will be adding scaling difficulty with "Scenario Dungeons" (AKA the main questline) which will make it even more interactive and fun. There are fun challenges like Hell Mode, the towers in Valley of Fallen Souls, and the PVP scene has a lot more to it than meets the eye. 

Dungeon Fighter Online is one of the least MMO-like MMOs to ever exist because of the meat of its gameplay being so unique and retro. There is fantastic pixel artwork done and you can tell this game had a lot of love put into it.

Party up with friends up to 4, or play alone if you want to. There are plenty of classes to choose from with multiple subclasses to boot for tons of replayability and flexible playstyles so there is, indeed, a little bit of something for everyone.

Big thing though - do not play the Steam client. There are weird issues with it on the account side of things and you're genuinely better off just downloading it off of the actual game's website.

> By default, you will have no "leveling assistance" bonuses like increased movement speeds, or higher damage without some form of payment.
> Unfortunately one of the cases where it's becomes significantly easier and better if someone is helping you through it.

120909680.review:
I do not use steam to play Dungeon Fighter, but i am a long time player of this game, I played during the beta stages of the game, and i watched it go through many different stages up to its current point.

I know new players don't really read reviews, and i know older players don't need a review of this game to jump back into it. Id like to say that this game has seen better days first and foremost, currently the community is sparce and they have jumped into this strange NEO worldspace that seems to have changed the overall feeling of the game. The classes are updated leaving plenty to be desired from older classes, specifically classes that utilize multi hits. And progress is consistently streamlined just to push you to the highest level with no difficulty no cares and not a whole lot of fun. I feel at this point the game is old enough that older players have their characters but they push newer players through all of the directed content and throw all of the side content on as an optional point of play as it really isn't necessary to touch for most characters and there is no point on getting involved in the economy of the game at this stage. I don't know the state of the games homeland but im sure its a reflection of interest in its home country but I could be wrong.

Its my hope that after watching this game grow, close, grow, close and then grow again that as it takes its next step into different games and different genres it wont forgets its roots. I have not played DNF Duel yet but i plan too. And im sure everyone has seen project overkill or bbq or whatever its next name is. Truthfully i hope that what they have done with dnf duel will be brought back to its orginal arcade style. Rather than moving on to overkill or bbq and removing the retro arcade style the game is known for. I believe the next course of the games development should instead revisit their original game and reinvigorate the arcade style game genre permanently for it. Allow the next wave of mobile and gacha games to take on that 3D landscape, games like Kurtzpel, Genshin, and Tower Of Fantasy should be allowed to rule in their new home. Please do not try to force DNF into a mold that was made for something elses playground and instead bring back a steady community of arcade fighters. If DNF Duel is a precursor to the next arcade style game of DNF becoming DNF 2. Than i believe alot of the old successes can be brought back while incorporating some of the new mechanics as well. Take the best of Dnf's snapshots. From my beta experience id say in terms of features that I personally like. And anyone can and will disagree would be. The Current state of itemization, hunting items as sets, and the raid system, Remove magic sealed items as i believe its a band aid to a system that only needed increased drop rates. The older pvp system before the Arena System. The games where much easier to find and im sure balance can be made by using a more modern system. The Explore club names are of course a helpful addition to carry over as it helps with managing friends and gaining bonuses for using multiple characters. The exploration area i believe is something brought over from Mabinogi which could probably have stayed there in my opinion as is completely skipped over as raids are the main function for end game. It would be nice for the focus of the game to remain in raids, dungeoning, and pvp. By providing rewards for dungeoning and pvping in the way that modern games do with cosmetic items and non cosmetic rewards or currencies to purchase equipment and item sets, im sure DNF could skip things like exploration zones unless they intend to incorporate a full on exploration type of arcade style by utilizing these zones in between cities and having players travel from zone to zone before getting to safe zones. Similar to other Free to play Sidescrollers. But the features are not as important to be re implented as preserving the core arcade style of DNF and incorporating the Art style, of DNF Duel. By re creating the original DNF format out of DNF Duel I believe that DNF will only secure its ability to move on from its current state. Bringing over what it has learned from DNF. And overall creating a better experience and a fresh start for anyone who has enjoyed the game over the years.



That being said. In its current stage. The game is still fun. Fatigue runs out about as quickly as you level. But its great nostalgia for anyone who has already played, and a nice time waster for those who can bring a group along to run few dungeons with. There is much less harshness to the game as there used to be. But enjoying the game as it is now im sure id play it for just as long. Absolutely give this game a try and keep a lookout for its future.

120768351.review:
This game is incredibly well made and incredibly fun.
I originally bought this game and a lot of DLC and a few in game purchased for it.
I enjoyed it a ton. It is a great game.
So why am I recommending against the game and saying you should not buy it?
Well, for one, the game purges any account that is inactive for 1 (one) month.
I had to go to the hospital at one point. When I returned my account was purged.
I contacted customer support, there was nothing they could do for me.
This is a game that relies on the player to play it nonstop or else they delete the account.
I do not recommend this game. We are all one bad event from being offline for a short while.
Bad events are inevitable in life. And nobody can ever hope to be sure they can be online playing their favorite game every single month.
This game is as such, very poorly managed, and the customer support can do nothing to help players.
To be honest, it seems a lot like a really well made predatory cash grab game with a Free to Play model added on top. 
The fact that it is so incredibly well made is what draws people into it.

119055085.review:
I've played DFO off and on since Nexon's initial release, till its shutdown, to the rerelease via Neople directly. I quit about a year and a half ago, but decided I should go ahead and download it via Steam (which can't be linked to existing accounts) for a quick romp through on a new account.

DFO used to be a game I wholeheartedly enjoyed and would sink hours into, but it doesn't feel the same anymore.

The current new player (or rather I should say new character) experience is depressingly boring, with most of the leveling process involving going through dungeons in which every single monster (including the bosses) can be killed with a single skill. This is made more annoying due to knowing how many of these bosses functioned prior to this. Many encounters that are hyped up in the story are literal jokes and completely undermines the plot as well as the player's time. If you're bored enough to sit through the leveling process, you do finally somewhat feel like you're playing a beat-em-up rather than a mobile game that can be played with one hand once you get closer to the later caps (I'd say around 90+). However, if you haven't played the game to know that it does get better, I envision the average player simply quitting long before then, but then the majority of the endgame content revolves around raids.

Most classes in the game have become increasingly homogenized as well, with most of the releases in the time since Neople began hosting it themselves just having an arsenal of screenwide nukes, and many of the more unique mechanics and skills of older classes often being phased out and replaced with... more screen-wide nukes. Many classes feel overly similar due to this behavior when that wasn't the case previously, and the game feels like much more of a giant number simulator than a beat-em-up.

The game has the standard battle-pass fare, constant items to buy in the shops, and continuously aggressive powercreep. All things I wouldn't care about if there was actually a game to play outside of the raid content at endgame, which again, used to not be an issue. This is further exacerbated by the game being designed around having multiple alts, including a stamina system on top of your standard MMO time-gating that prevents playing a single character for too long. Stamina on its own isn't particularly an issue at endgame, again due to the time-gating existing on top of it.

Generally speaking, DFO is a game that has many cool ideas, and things I'd LOVE to see done as well as it (or at least as well as they used to be), and was in my opinion, probably the most enjoyable blend of RPG and beat-em-up around. Unfortunately, the current state of the game is just not enjoyable, nor has been for the last few years, which is a shame as this is a game I truly loved and had literal thousands of hours in.

It's free, so there's no harm in trying it, but personally, this is a title to stay away from. Perhaps if this was about 10 years ago, you'd be in for a treat.

118689059.review:
There have always been connection issues, especially when the Peer to Peer system was less polished, but it seems like the game stability has taken a sharp decline. Connection issues are rampant and tech support doesn't listen to you when you tell them you're not running VM software and feeds you back into the support queue in an endless loop. It's a status quo of not fixing any problems. 

DFO used to be amazing when it hadn't yet been gutted and sold. Now the game is a cash cow of exploitative addiction mechanics, wheels and flashing lights everywhere, no difficulty in sight as NPCs clutter the battlefield robbing you of any real game experience, leaving you wondering when the gameplay is actually going to begin. Sky tower used to actually provide just a slight bit of difficulty. When I first played years ago, you actually had to fight through the stages to progress. Now you're level 30 within 30 minutes of gameplay -- and that is assuming that you can manage to stay connected to be allowed to navigate the messy GUI which was made even more cluttered by all the inane simultaneously running "events" that trample over each other to try to keep you engaged, because the ruined difficulty and stages and copious amounts of bloat certainly don't.

116359697.review:
This game was cool back in 2010, if you have nostalgia for it maybe level a character a bit to experience the old dungeons and soundtrack.  Then leave.

It's pay to win, first off.  Check the hours I put in - I'm still more or less on the bottom of the food chain after years of meticulous daily grind.  Even after re-farming entire sets of gear just to have the most-optimal epics according to some 3rd party software I had to download just to calculate the stats, I'm still begging just to get in to the actual endgame content next to all the whales with amps and enchants bought by selling Cera items in the auction house.

Second, the community is pretty toxic.  Decent players or guilds exist but they are outnumbered.  Expect casual racism, sexism, and other bigotry and expect not to speak up about it (or about anything, really) without getting harassed and blocked by the people who lead the endgame raid groups, preventing you from progressing.

And what makes those things worse is, this isn't like WoW or something where there was at least a world of stuff to explore and do outside of endgame raids.  This game is pretty much entirely a linear sprint to the one or two current endgame raids which you will then repeat HUNDREDS of times exactly the same way just to farm your gear, only to end up...  still underpowered.  Because you still need hundreds of millions of gold to buy avatars, amps, reinforcements, enchants, emblems, titles, creatures and so on just to pull your own weight.  I like grind.  I came here for some grind to get me through covid isolation but this is not healthy, it is the mind-numbing, repetitive-strain-injury-inducing kind.

I regret the time I spent here the last two years.  It stopped being fun but it was hard to come to terms with everything I'd invested being for nothing.  The only winning move is not to play, because once you play you can't quit without throwing away all that time you invested.

EDIT:  The only thing I wanted to add was how much it pained me to write this review because I really, really used to love this game way back.  A lot of people clearly worked really hard to bring it to life, so it just really sucks that this is the state it's in.

116229448.review:
This will be long and somewhat ranty review. I wish there was a better rating system on Steam because DFO falls somewhere in the middle between thumbs up and thumbs down. I gave it a cautious thumbs up but this game has a lot of flaws and caveats.

DFO is one of the most fun games while also one of the most infuriating I have played over the past 6 years or so, with some longer breaks here and there. On the good side, you have some fun and engaging side-scrolling combat reminiscent of the good old arcade games like Final Fight and Streets of Rage. You have a huge range of classes many of which feel unique, not an easy feat to achieve. It starts very easy, too easy in fact, unlike 5 years ago where even from the start you had to at least pay attention, and then very gradually becomes harder and harder though there is a very big spike past 90 that for some classes can be very frustrating.

On the neutral side, there is a 15 Euro subscription per month that gives you some benefits and you can play more on any given character, increasing the so called fatigue points, FP in short, from 156 to iirc 276. To offset this in case you cannot play that much, 276 will easily take you about 1 1/2 to 2 hours to burn through, you can double the FP cost but also get double experience though you will quickly outlevel dungeons and get reduced experience. You can opt to skip low level main quest content and hop over to the level appropiate main quest area, but you lose quite a bit of gold and potentially gear, which means you might have too low level gear now, so that is a two edged sword. You also get a legendary weapon for leveling giving you a signicant power boost if you so wish it compensating for the faster level process if you go for the increase FP use option. You also get a discount on some dungeon materials and a minor daily reward like extra entry materials for a certain dungeon.
Gear does not change your characters looks apart from the weapon, for your character you need to buy skins. There are events which can give you a free skin on occasion, but usually you have to buy them and they are not cheap, in part because skins are a set of about 12 parts, like hair, face,etc. and each gives a little bonus, some of which are important like giving you a +1 bonus to your main class buff.

On the bad side, there is the P2W aspect that is quite infuriating because first you have to qualify to be allowed to purchase anything and there are 5 stages of privilige for which you have to pay 150 Euros to qualify for the third, which finally allows you to access the in game cash shop. It has the typical Korean weapon upgrade system that at higher tiers require you to invest hundreds of millions and other material in the thousands to upgrade and it has not only a chance to fail but at the top endcan destroy your weapon. This is exceptionally grating for the average gamer since just getting the best items requires a lot of grind as usual in Korean MMOs.
Next is the overabundance of crafting and instance access materials. It is overwhelming especially for a new player. While there is at least on the newer materials a description what and where they can be used in many instances you will still be confused what exactly you can upgrade or exchange them for and what is and what is not important. The game itself is not telling you much all in all and you will have to rely on online guides, some of which can be found on YT.
The worst aspect is imho the raiding. Now do not get me wrong I have nothing per se against raids. They can be up to 16 players large where you send a group of 4 into different locations in the dungeon, a cool concept. Sadly there are some very grating design flaws. 
For one each has an individual material requirement you have to either farm or gather through an event which further clutters your inventory and stash, a completely uneccessary hassle since you are already limited to do them once a day and twice a week. 
Then there is the fact that especially when you learn the dungeon in the so called "Guide mode" you are not only required to learn the bosses general attack patterns but almost every single one of them has at least one if not two one shot patterns that you have to memorize or get one shot. That in a high stress situation because apart from that the bosses deal high damage just with their normal attacks and they are very spongy so long as you are not vastly out-gearing them will lead to frequent frustrating deaths. You are limited to a certain limit of revives per attempt, ranging usually from 5-10 and they eat up revive coins. These coins once you reach 0 get refilled once a week to 3 and otherwise you either rely on events or have to buy them via hard cash. You can easily burn 30 revives in the initial phase of learning the highest level of current raid, because there are normally around 5 end bosses and 5-10 mid bosses, each with their own patterns and one shot mechanics. "Guide" mode has easier variants but the grating part is that they are supposed to help you learn the specifics yet burn through your coins and therefore incentive in the most abusive way to buy more revives. That is for me unacceptable. Yes you can go back to the starting area and wait a short time to "heal". 
Problem is though that you have to start the dungeon all over and while you can redo the fights and learn it a little better, you have a time limit of about 30 minutes. There are only so many attempts before you want to just alt-F4 out of the game and take a day or more off from the game.
Lastly customer service. Frankly it is abysmal. I had to give up my Steam account becasue they refused to let me change to my new e-mail adress because I lost access to my old Microsoft one, telling me that I should ask Mircosoft to reinstate it which I told them I had tried mutliple times to no avail.
A friend of mine who tried the game out and played for about 100 hours STILL has no access to anything, not even the web browser cash shop and frankly gave up playing it, he did not even come back when the current Blitz event came, preferring to level a new alt in WoW instead.
I am also not sure if it is still a thing but when I started on my second account there were regular annoying captchas popping up in the middle of a dungeon run which did not pause the game, which could lead to your death because you cannot do anything while the enemies are still attacking you. This is, or was, a anti-bot measure but all it does, or did, was infuriate you. The game actually does not tell you this but the only way to get around this is to send a message to support.

TL:DR version: Really fun gameplay and great variety of classes, but horrible scarcely explained systems, bloated amount of crafting, exceedingly punishing raids for beginners and entrance materials and some really infuriating P2W aspects on top of the typical Korean MMO grind.

113089717.review:
Disclaimer: **I've played on and off since early 2000s. Back then it was run by (old) Nexon so my game time on Steam isn't exactly reflective of my actual time in game.**

This game is great even if it's a little flawed. Lots of people still play, especially endgame content. They update the game frequently and have a new event every month. There is usually one livestream on Twitch every so often so the devs can answer questions and interact with the community. Despite a dip in profits in Q4 2021 this franchise spawned 2 other games: Project BBQ and Overkill. It's far from dead.

Most complaints are based around the Steam version like the captcha and login/account issues. Just play through their launcher. EZ. I will agree the FP system isn't the best, but I found it helps encourage playing your other characters. Since most drops around endgame levels drop both character AND account bound items, you can just play on your alts then funnel everything to your main character. 

The story is fairly interesting but most people I've introduced the game to just mash the skip button and blow through the story bits. The cut scenes are either motion comic styled or a nice fully animated/voiced scene and you can watch them later if you missed/skipped any. There are also missions which exist solely to provide a little extra lore and have no impact on story progression. 

Progression is pretty linear until endgame where you're grinding raids for random mythics. Leveling is stupid fast the first 10-20 or even up to 30. Joining a guild that has the 10% exp buff going is a great way to blast through early content. Leveling slows a little between 50-70 or 80 but it's not bad at all. Around 95 is when you'll start the endgame gearing process and looking to min/max your characters.

You don't need to spend money to get paid avatar items from the cash shop but yes the option does exist. You can buy things from the auction house for in game currency. Most people would complain about the clone avatars or the pets that provide a little extra stats but if somebody wants to spend $ to make their char look cool, support the game, AND help our raid group kill bosses faster.... I'm ok with that. Also, I don't play pvp in this game but if you like the characters, just wait for dnf duel and go play that.

Anyways, if you're on the fence about the game just try it by using their website to download the launcher. If you want help or just to join a guild for free buffs, I run the guild Lechery on Cain server. All are welcome to join.

107630297.review:
Having played this game from the old nexon days and the reboot by Neople and still currently playing I can say without a doubt that this game definitely fits a niche audience. New players wanting to play a nice beat em up game with some depth might find this game fun, but if they want to play some of the end game content they'll have to spend a ton of time to get their gear up and interact with the offline community like Reddit. Hopefully the next cap to be released will address these issues so that newer players can play casually and have fun while also remain challenging for older players.

As for events, I'd say everything has gone down hill over the years. The events were usually just repeats and unfortunately due to the NA server having a small team, we don't see those exclusive events like the Wild Wild West event. I'm sure if there were a larger consistent player base that we'd get more fun and experimental events, but as of now it's pretty much either sit down and get rewards to gear or get gear by grinding.

Overall I'd give this game an honest 6/10. It's good and if you like beat em ups I'd bump it up to 7/10 but it's not very new player friendly, and the customization has been a rollercoaster. Some balancing to open up avenues of character customization would definitely make this game better, as well as content that can be fun for players who just want the challenge of a traditional beat em up would definitely benefit this game a ton.

-Simple mechanics *easy to learn hard to master*

-Fatigue system - Yes! so you can jump to other character. They did this as business strategy I guess. They make more money by attracting you to buy avatar for other characters. 

This is just how I see the game and it can be different to other players too. Overall! 8/10. I'm still satisfied with the game.

106321123.review: Ok, so I just played in the DNF Duel beta and it was a lot of fun so I thought I would check out DFO. I was wondering why this game had mixed reviews but after 21 hours of game play there is a reason I'm going to stop playing this game now. No matter what level you get or what class awakenings you achieve you will always look like your base class at level one. The game is very misleading by having all the sub classes have specific skins in the create a character screen and showing you what level they unlock at (even letting you try them in a practice mode with those skins on) but when you reach the level you change classes you will still look like you do at level one. I understand for some people this might not bother them but for me its a deal breaker to look the same at level one as I do at level one hundred. I used to be a big Ragnarok Online fan which had a ton of classes which you changed into when you achieved them so I think its dumb to not change base skins when you class change. The only reason Dungeon Fighter is set up this way is greed, it's so they can resell the skins for a limited time once a year for real money. Which is crazy because we are just talking about the base class skins, I think it would be fine for them to sell skins sure but to not even let the player have the base class skin is just ridiculous to me. The second I realized the game is like this I instantly stopped playing. I highly doubt I will come back, will probably uninstall after writing this review. It's a shame too because I love 2D beat em up games and I was having fun playing the game. Not getting to have my sub classes skin is just too asinine for me to continue playing this game though. Shame for DFO to miss so hard with that, they definitely know what they are doing with that misleading character creation screen. Wasted potential for a game.

106123318.review:
I've played thousands of hours of this game on the client from the developer's website. DFO is an incredibly unique game that no other game can quite scratch the itch of. It's an MMO beat-em-up RPG, and if I had to compare it to another MMO in terms of feel, it'd be Black Desert. If you play, play the version through the DFONeople website, as the Steam client apparently has problems. I quit in early 2021, having played from the relaunch in March 2015. Until I quit I had sold runs of the hardest content on the hands down worst class in the game for several years, so it really is down to how much you're willing to master your character and optimize your gear.

I love this game, but I would describe it as a beautiful little hut underneath of a mountain of trash. If you're an endgame player, you've been cozy while this mountain of trash built up around you. If you're a new player, you must dig through the endless trash to try to find something worthwhile. For example, many new players report being automatically banned after their first day and having to manually appeal it to be able to play again. I really wonder what percentage of new players actually do this. I'd guess less than 10%. This game has a lot of problems, and most target new players for some reason. Also, the game is peer-to-peer so unless you have a good internet connection, don't even try. If you are not in NA, northern South America, are unwilling to find a European guild, or able speak Chinese, you will likely be a solo-only player. Also, because of peer-to-peer, sometimes if one person crashes it'll crash the entire group, potentially losing you your clear. 

If you're wondering about the lore - you don't play this game for the lore, and the answer is always Hilder.

The combat is some of the best I've played. Skills are responsive, the abilities are flashy, and most classes can pull some really slick combos that are incredibly satisfying. Your skill can carry you through most encounters even with lackluster gear. Except you won't need any skill while leveling until you're at least level 90. This game encourages alts (more below), and as such they've streamlined the leveling, making it way too easy and boring.

You cannot do relevant group content without having epics, which are gotten by using account-bound materials you primarily get from doing raids. You can farm Legendary gear to be able to do the solo mode of the first raid of the level cap, and the previous level cap's raids (though probably solo only as well, because of elitism). The solo version will reward fewer materials than the group version, but it's better than nothing. If you're a new player who can't get carried, expect to be running solo for several months before becoming a "real" character. Groups will just accept somebody with 10x your damage. Raids also drop materials for upgrading your epics. And when I say upgrading your epic, I mean it's the same item but with an extra 12% multiplier on your damage. Per piece. Plus set effects. Because not only does your item have a set, but your upgrades have a set that stacks with your set, so you can set while you set. I'm not joking.

The wall for new players is obscene. So the easiest way to become an endgame player is to get carried until you're geared enough to stand on your own. If you have a guild that'll do it for free, that's amazing. Usually, you'll be buying carries with gold. These prices are usually low enough to be farmed within 1 FP bar, so it's not too bad, I guess.

But wait, what's an FP bar? Fatigue points. That's how this game deters bots from leveling to max and grinding a bunch of gold in a day. Dungeons are broken into rooms, and every time you enter a new room it costs 1 FP. If you run out of FP points, you cannot enter a dungeon until they refresh back to full tomorrow. They give new players a bunch of FP recovery potions to supplement this, but it's not enough. Many new players end up frustrated due to wanting to continue playing their character, but unable to until tomorrow. And then find they've been auto-banned if they try to log in the next day! Good job, Neople. Endgame players don't really care about fatigue. Fatigue points are per character, and we only do a few dungeons/character/day. Past that it's weekly dungeons and raids for our upgrades. If you want to farm and run out of FP on one character, you just swap to another, because you have a dozen to choose from. Again, new players are screwed here.

This game *is* pay-to-win, but it's not that f2p players can't compete. F2P players just have to grind for gold more. Pets/Titles/Auras have stats, but those and almost everything else in the cash shop is tradeable. Buy budget options and use those until you get a character to BiS gear, then buy the BiS ones every 2 years or so. They also sell tickets that stop your items from breaking due to high reinforcement, but reinforcing armor is usually useless and is only useful on weapons above +12. Do not ever go for +13. Do not amp. Do not compete with whales. These are futile efforts. Some of these whales are C-level execs who don't care if they drop millions of dollars as long as they are the best.

All in all, the gameplay is extremely fun, but the systems around the gameplay are extremely flawed. I hope some day they can fix this game and just let people enjoy the combat instead of having to commit to endless grinds to stay relevant.

105650851.review:
There's so much content it's confusing what makes sense to do.  Questline Dungeons have a default difficulty that isn't very fun for someone looking for a challenge.  

Personally I think this game just got too cumbersome.  When it was a Lvl 1-60 or 1-70'ish game it was much better.  The gear system is really great.  The default questline difficulty for dungeons messed the game up. Also the game now has such a huge level spread and less new players, so it's hard to find a group to run dungeons with anymore.  This game was always much funner with at least one more person to run dungeons with. 

There needs to be a dungeon fighter 2 or a complete revamp like WoW did, squishing the level range down, streamlining the areas so that there aren't so many outdated questlines, gear, etc.  

This game has some very novel ideas that are really unique to it.  It would be great to see more games take on some of these ideas (like fatigue points).

101712703.review:
Ignore the hours played, since the game highly incentivizes you to leave it running 24/7.

TLDR; The game requires spending at least $100-$150 in order to be playable past a couple weeks.

I decided it give it a shot, since I was feeling nostalgic for the Nexon days. I got into it pretty hard, until shortly after reaching the level cap. The endgame progression requires stockpiling epic armor sets. This is an RNG progression nightmare, but not really my main complaint. Naturally, trying to hoard all those pieces fills up your storage pretty quick. I saw the safe upgrade in the shop for $1, so I loaded up on the premium currency CERA and went to buy it, only to realize that you can't even use the in-game shop until you reach "Steel Tier". How does one reach "Steel Tier", you ask? By spending ONE HUNDRED AND FIFTY dollars on their webstore, which doesn't include storage upgrades.

That's right. In order to store more than the base number of items (practically required for epic progression), you have to spend $150 or wait for 6-12 months for them to sell a buyable safe upgrade for $20 (What a bargain /s). It's not only safe upgrades. Even the starter pack is locked behind this paywall. $150 just for the right to BUY the starter pack. What a joke.

100755967.review:
I haven't played this in awhile but it was always the best thing for scratching that old Streets of Rage/Ragnarok Battle Offline itch.  A Beat-em-up with RPG progression? Yes please!  Suuuuuper smooth & responsive combat, lots of cool mechanics, and many different playstyles.  Witch was always my favorite; I love racking up combos in the 100's of hits.

Folks mentioning endgame here, but if you're a casual you'll have plenty of fun just playing the many classes thru the leveling system.  Some grind here and there in that they pull the old "one quest at a time in the same dungeon" trick; so definitely don't go into anything extra because you'll replay the same (slightly randomized) map a few times.  There is this limit where you can only go into so many "rooms" total per day; but it was ~150 way back, and for me that was ~3hrs playtime.  In other words, way more than I needed on a given day.  And you can just swap characters if you need a little more fun :)

The worst thing I experienced (which isn't bad) was that they seemed to have ramped up the XP generation and reduced the dungeon difficulty to make it "more new player friendly".  So you could easily over-level early on, and that's without all the new player & holiday event things they throw at you.  Could be worse, but could also be a little more challenging.  I kinda want to be afraid of dying at least once per run (you get 3+ tries).

97209118.review:
The game is alright for some time, but it really suffers from the same motivation killing loops that almost all Korean MMOs suffer from in endgame. The current endgame content usually requires tediously long hours of grinding for 1 specific thing at a time over the span of a month...and that's just 1 thing. Every character that wants to participate in endgame content like the Sirocco raid or Black Purgatory runs has to have 1st or 2nd best in slot enchants, as well as the very minimum of earrings, magic stone, and sub equip being amped up to the minimum of 8 (the exception is obviously Aeterna syn bags). Not to mention the cost of entry for all content is that there is necessarily a need for buffer characters, which in of itself has an insane cost to fund. I wish the endgame content wasn't so formulaic like every other Korean MMO (and to some degree the genre of gacha-style MMOs as a whole). 
Oh well, spent like 80 bucks in the nearly 2k hours I've played over 3 years. Still wouldn't recommend to anyone.

played the game for a small amount of time and I can already tell why specific points were made in both the positive and negative reviews.

Not going to repeat everyone but it's a game you have to try out yourself, basically in the plained terms someone can understand that doesn't know much. It's a beat'em up game in mmo form so you fight in a side scrolling world while having the large amount of skills that you'd have in a mmorpg game. Even ctrl and alt are skill buttons for default.  If you love beat'em games you'll definitely find enjoyment in this, however one major thing considering the country of origin. They love to prevent players for playing long periods of time and or charge you to continue you playing. This game uses a energy meter similar to a mobile game. You run dungeon instances and lose "Fatigue points" until you hit zero. once that happens you aren't allowed to play any more dungeons unless you somehow have restore potions that are allowed a few uses daily and reset on daily reset (obviously). People have had many issues with the game but if you download (it takes a long time so be prepared) and don't run into any problem you should be fine to go forward. this Fatigue feature is probably the worst thing ever stopping players from doing everything they want in one game session. If they somehow think about removing it and fix the other issues people have with the game it could easily jump 30% in positive rating. But a sequel is in the works so they probably have a small team on this just to hold it until the new game launches... sad days.

96488818.review:
Edit 9/16/21: I'm glad this review got traction but I have to bring this to light for people who are only reading this now. As of late August/early September, DFO received a new game director who actually plays the game and understood how bad the state of the game was. Most if not everything addressed here in the review was brought up to Neople's internal management and are slowly being fixed over time. Please understand that at the time of this review in late July, things were horrible. I sincerely hope to give this game another try when everything comes, but for now take this review as being slightly outdated.

[h1]What Makes DFO Great[/h1]

Gameplay and dungeon mechanics such as making the difficulty single-player based is great. You’ll find plenty to do if all you want to do is figure out which class is for you.

[h1]Neutral Grounds[/h1]

"The real game begins at endgame” as well as constant FOMO events that prolong your playtime via AFK. Want best rewards? Play 3 hours. Generic schlock.

[h1]The Stupid[/h1]

Endgame content is boring, and I mean it. The level 100 cap makes Genshin Impact’s grind appealing, because if you’re seriously that unlucky you’re gonna be spending an upwards of 1 year to even fully gear yourself out with no alternatives. It’s so mind-numbingly dumb how the most reliable way to get gear is both time and resource locked, with only a 10% chance of dropping one item from a pool of 120+ epics. Fatigue in this game is a joke.

This game is Pay-to-Win. Call it for what it is. If you want long-term investments, such as pets, auras, avatars, or titles - the latter of which will provide you with very important stat and skill boosts -  and wish to obtain it through in-game money, good luck. The economy of the game is in shambles, where titles and avatars cost millions of dollars, upwards of 200 million for some classes. Do you want to know how much you can earn every day? Supposing you get a routine down, you will gain an upwards of 10 million a day, provided you have 12 - 16 hours of your life to spare, or you can spend 12 - 16 seconds swiping your credit card for 20x the gains.

The community is their favorite word they love throwing around: Trash. [b]These people are brainlet meta-slaves who only see the top 0.1% and want to follow them to a T, and anything less is “trash” or “garbage” to them[/b]. Guilds in this game don’t even alleviate it, sometimes they even purposefully encourage it. They’re a complete joke, to the point where this can’t even be a parody. Wearing great gear but not best-in-slot? Trash. Playing a class not within Top 20 Meta? Trash. Obtain something that’s good but not the best? Trash. Even old content from 5 levels prior needs absolute meta gear to do. For instance, one level 95 raid where the best in slot epics back then are equivalent in power to the level 100 legendary-tier items, they no longer cut it. [b]You now need level 100 epics to even do the hard mode of a level 95 raid.[/b] Remember what I said about the economy a paragraph earlier? It’s mandatory you’re seen with these items, otherwise you’re not getting into a party. The community demands 2 second kills, rather than 20 second kills. At this rate you aren’t even playing the game. You can’t even disable global chat, you’re forced to see this stupidity every day. The block list only has a max capacity of 100 people, and even then you’re still gonna see idiots. At one point, one person was whining like a child about how the game was unfun, their favorite classes were non-meta, and this went on for 30 minutes in guild chat. They refused to take a break or quit, only opting to whine every time something inconvenienced him. They were also toxic, calling everybody who didn’t know about something noobs, and told everybody to suck it. They weren’t kicked because they single-handedly carried the guild in contribution. And this was one of the tamer guilds. [b]TL;DR: This community destroys IQ. They’re all smooth brains.[/b]

This game’s identity is in an existential crisis. While at base it has beat-em-up DNA, the devs dictated they needed to fit in MMORPG-styled classes. There are 3 classifications. Pure DPS are essentially straightforward damage dealers, Synergy DPS are party supports in which they’ll provide extra damage or benefits to the team while being able to deal damage, and Buffers are as the name implies. The downside of this is that the party system is absolutely curved in such a way that if you want to duo with a friend, one of them must be a Buffer. In solo play, it’s scaled to 1 person. In duo play, it’s scaled 133% harder, rather than 33%, meaning that you need to be overgeared for the dungeon to properly do damage, unless you have a Buffer, because a Buffer enables you to have stats equivalent to 3x your normal. You need to be doing the equivalent of 4x the effort compared to solo. You are also expected to play a Buffer and treat it with as much effort as you would your main, meaning you must gear them equally as much as your main instead of treating it as your alt.

The game has “sell” runs. I’m well aware that certain games have people who sell dungeon runs, but the difference here is that DFO has no queue system to bypass buying dungeon runs. If you want to join a fast party, you must pay them to take you, and even then there’s no guarantee you’re taken. Combine that with the prior paragraph, it’s a disaster. If the “seller” doesn’t see you with appropriate gear, it doesn’t matter if you’re willing to pay 3x more, they’ll take somebody else. To accentuate how ignorant the community is, how they proceed to sell runs are on the scale of wannabe capitalists. They have a saying too. “If you are not a seller, you are a customer”. You are just a commodity. A source of money to them. You think being in a guild will give you free carries? Nope, they’ll still ask you pay them for the effort.

Class favoritism exists. Female Slayers get all the attention of the devs, because they are both waifu material and overpowered. While most of my time was spent on them because of the natural flow that I like in classes, even I could tell this is not how I should only be playing. In Korea, the 62nd class is the Blade, which is the 5th subclass of the Female Slayer. [b]Her launch event contained free epics and a free mythic of your choice while the rest of the playerbase, over the course of the 100 cap still struggle with finding epics/mythics of their desires, and don't even get so much as a single scrap to transfer over.[/b] Meanwhile some classes such as the Male Grappler are so underpowered that despite being fun, nobody plays them because they’re suboptimal from a lack of meaningful damage or poor resource management. What madness is this?

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

This is a hard skip unless you wanna see how bad the game is, or just want to play for the class fantasies. Look at my time. I spent 1,200 hours and I never interacted with anybody because they’re all stupid. I made it to endgame, did raids solo, and it was the most hollow experience there ever was. Neople’s future projects, including a 2.5D Remake of this game + Project BBQ, the 3rd person Action RPG of DFO, don’t exactly spark hype if they want to run this game so far into the ground it found a home in China.

You are better off playing Guide/Squad mode difficulty the entire time than dealing with a community this dumb. Better yet, coming full circle, just play Genshin Impact if you want a better experience solo and multiplayer.

I’m only giving this an extended amount of time for the Blade, who is likely not coming until 2022. But after that, it’s straight to the uninstall and remove from account bin.

P.S. If you play on Steam and get unlucky, Neople bans your account under the assumption you're a bot. If you wish to appeal, you're waiting an entire month for a response. That should make you consider your time.

Update to the review
================

So I've been seeing more and more complain and whine about being "Banned" from the game. Neople, the publisher and developer of the game have been putting trade restrictions and temporary bans on people to keep potential gold sellers and scammers from immediately creating new accounts and going right back to what they were doing before. Ruining the game. 

It is a counter measure to protect the integrity of the game and prevent the economy of the game to inflate. Do not mistake this as you not being allowed to play the game or that Neople doesn't want you to play, they just want to try and stop the problematic people.

91497506.review:
11 years old veteran here recently returning to DFO.
DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME HOLY SHIT.

You enter the game after a few years of not playing, and you are hit with being trade restricted.
There's no way to lift it (The quest it mentions for unlock it (???!?!), Ominous Energy 1, and 2, has been removed from the game) and you are forced to send a ticket in and wait for the trade restriction to be lifted.
It can take anywhere between couple of days to weeks, and you are not guaranteed a response.

"It trade restriction so bad? Isn't it just with other players?"
Wrong.
Your inventory gets filled up and you can't destroy useless items, because trade restriction also limits your ability to discard "valuable" items. 
Many quests require "cubes", materials you obtain from disassembling. YOU CAN'T DISASSEMBLE TO DO THOSE QUEST.
This includes key quests like unlocking certain equipment slots or, from what I've heard, one of the Anton quest that's required, from a Reddit post 2 years ago?
You are literally barred from progression, not just mildly inconvenienced.
Until this is resolved, this game is playable, but hilariously insidious in its treatment of you.

Worst part of all this is, if you didn't know and you charged CENA?
YOU CAN'T SPEND THE MONEY YOU CHARGED THE GAME WITH BECAUSE OF THIS TRADE RESTRICTION.
IT'S A LITERAL FUCKING SCAM.

Give me my old DFO back.

Update after 2 weeks:
The trade restriction has been lifted and I played for about 2 weeks or so.
The game just isn't very good right now.
All those memories I had about various bosses and area are now just filler contents; Nothing below max level matters anymore. Now the only thing you can and should do in this game is:
1. Get to level 100
2. Farm Ghent for full gear
3. Farm 5-5 and 2-2 for full legendary gear
3.5.1 Farm Swap gears at Operation Hope
3.5.2 Farm Guide of Wisdom for full Epic gear
4. Farm Sirocco

They basically threw away 90% of the game's contents and settings and made it irreverent. The only thing that matters is endgame. So you sit through maybe a week or two of boring grind to get to 100, and then sit through grinds that are time-gated to 5 times per day or 2 times per day, or based on weekly restrictions, or whatever.

It just isn't fun. It's all repetitive and boring.
I stopped myself after I realize I am spending 5 hours farming 5-5's and 2-2's across multiple characters per day, just upgrading gear to the next color. Screw this.

91433704.review:
I've played this game almost 2k hours and i do not recommend this game.

Lack of players. Unlike KDNF, you will have to wait a long time to start a dungeons and raids.
Mostly waiting for a buffer to join. You will see a lot of party titles : ' Looking for a Sader '
So i always have something like youtube playing next to dfo.

This game is pay to win. 
Yes, you can do the events and get gears, items, +12weap, rare avas, emblems everything. But those events are only held once a while. 
To get minimum requirements to do final content, it will take you months. 

Fatigue system. You can only play your character 150~290+pot fatigue points - (1~2 hours of play time). 
Meaning, you have to create many characters to actually enjoy this game.  Which conflicts with Second statement - this game is pay to win -
More characters = more gold you gonna need.

Desync/lag : IDK if the server is unstable or it's individual player's internet connection or both, but there are a LOT of disconnecting issues when you play with people. 
Either screen turns black and someone disappears -making the dungeon harder to finish- or you just can't hit the monster cuz someone is lagging. 

Tickets - late reply or not solving.
I have submitted at least 10 tickets and none of them are solved correctly.
For example, i was banned for 3 days for using a mechanical keyboard. 
I know for sure, it was the new keyboard i got cuz i Never launch Any program when i play dfo. It's always been DFO / chrome or DFO / audio player. 
When  i got this new keyboard, it had some extra buttons like next song, stop song, turn on/off lights on the keyboard. Those were the only buttons i've used. 
Few days after i've used this keyboard, i was banned. 
I did not even install any programs related to the new keyboard and never plugged in 2nd USB port cuz i've never seen a keyboard w/2 usb male ports. 
So, as conclusion, i was banned for using audio related buttons and light buttons on a new keyboard. 
When i submitted a ticket about this, i  explained every single details explaining i was banned for using 3rd program, i did not use any programs, i know for sure it was the new keyboard, can you investigate on this and un-ban me?
The reply i got was : " you were banned for using 3rd program blah blah "
Yea i already know that lol so can you investigate and help me understand?
- still waiting on reply. 
When you submit a ticket, do not expect to get it solved. 

So i have talked sh1t about this game and warned new incoming players.
But this game is fun overall. 

I am an old gamer, i started playing this game again cuz i played this game when i was young when nexon was in charge. Neople is doing much much better than nexon. 
In fact, Nexon did not do anything with their games and eventually gave up. At the end, half of the players were using hacks.
I still remember that Nexon sold Permanent Silenced TRGs, AKs on Sudden Attack only few weeks before shutting down the game. Shocking.
Nexon was trash.
Neople on the other hand is doing something they should be doing even thou it's just copy and paste from KDFO and just translating it. I am ok with that. 
When you experience the worst, something normal is satisfying. 

I will keep playing dfo cuz for me it's still fun and i can manage the issues, 
but if you are looking for a new game to play, you might wanna consider twice.

Never gotten to endgame before. Despite my hours, I'm still basically a newbie.

88810287.review:
Just try the game. It's fun and has a lot of customization and beautifully animated skills to use.  There's three simple points I want to give to new players though.

1. Trade bans happens to all new Steam players (for whatever reason) and it usually only lasts a week or so. If you care that much about it, just download the official client instead. 

2. There is 50+ classes in this game. Try every single class. They're all incredibly unique, and many have been unexpectedly fun for me. Don't just "pick a main because he looks cool" or because you were too lazy to make alts. You might end up hating that characters play-style. Pick a class based on how they play not appearance. You're in for a long ride, so have fun with it. Make alt characters as much as you can so you can mess around with everything.

3. This game is NOT PAY 2 WIN. IT'S PAY FOR CONVENIENCE. Seriously, the amount of idiots that wasted $100 on something they didn't understand, or don't make alt chars is astounding. You can NOT buy gear that is worthwhile directly anyway, you simply use in-game gold to refine/enhance gears. Every single thing in this game can be gotten by simply playing the dungeons. RNG is king, so if you don't get a full set of epic gear in one week, that's normal. Some people are lucky, some are even unluckier than you. It doesn't matter anyway, you aren't meant to stick to one character.

86285073.review:
This game used to be so fun.. Keywords used to.
Now it's filled with so many different anti-botting mechanics that you are guaranteed to be inconvenienced by at least one every time you play.
Trade restrictions? Check. Stamina systems to keep you from playing? Check. Account ban because you used Steam? Check.

On top of that the game play has been dumbed down to the point where you are going to 1 hit kill everything from levels 1 all the way to 95. (Which is a huge chore to go through, mind you.)

This game uses another launcher to do the entire download by the way and it has some of the slowest download speeds I've ever witnessed. 
Normally using Steam downloads I can download a 20GB game in under an hour however using the Dungeon Fighter Online launcher it took me 4 hours (what the actual f**k) to download this 20GB game. If this game is going to be on Steam just let us use Steam to download the god d*mn thing.

I forgot to mention that this game is very pay to win as well, the "cosmetic" outfits in the cash shop actually have stat boosts on them that will give you an advantage over non-paying players. The pets must be purchased from the cash shop and can equip their own gear which gives you yet another stat boost over non-paying players.

Not recommended unless you like games with zero challenge and don't mind not being able to play as much as you want to.
