85178641.review:
Before anything, I would advise to play the game thorugh the DFO page instead of the steam client. This is due to steam having more issues than neople's game client and because of random bans to people.

Now onwards with the review.

DFO is a mmo beat em up in which you go through dungeons killing enemies, picking up loot, leveling classes, and learning poweful skills. The game has over 50 classes, so you can certainly have a class to play. My personal advise: PLAY WHAT YOU THINK IS COOLER. Everything does well on endgame and the only class that you will use sooner or later is Crusader (Female or male), so just take a look at the classes, see which one catches your eye and then go dungeon clearing.

The graphics are pretty ok and make the game suitable for low spec gamers. I used to play it in a very old laptop so there you have it. Audiowise, music is good and dialogue is in korean since its a korean mmo. Animated scenes have their own volume setting too. Gameplay wise, is like any other mmo. You get skills, you get a skill bar, you got consumables, you got classes. You can customize your skill hotkeys and other things like profession for example. You can also add hotkeys for centering the loot all in one place (only once per dungeon) and to unstuck yourself. 

One thing I don't like that much is that TP (another type of skill points) are tied to a few pvp quests and that can be a huge downer for someone who doesnt like to pvp, Fspit and Ffighter need to do pvp quest to acces higher tier stuff so that was surprising the first time I saw it. Just note that the game is still pretty much alvie because fo the pvp and the upcoming fighting game. However PVP and PVE are not the same. PVP has a lot of technicalities like how to chain proper combos to abuse of aerial on your adversary. So dont stress yourself If you are suffering from the pvp questline or because you pvp and get obliterated by a sword.

Overall, I've played the game on the game client before (a lot actually, used to be a Fspit main and swap to a sader main because I liked the class), and now I'm playing it in the steam client because I changed laptops and just to have it on my steam library as a reminder of the fun times I used to have. The game is pretty good, there is people still playing the game even after all this eyars so definitely give it a try if you are interested.

84691684.review:
This review is from me, a gamer with 6.3k hours with steam record, and countless hours without it.
It's a great game in a macroscopic point of view, but it has it's own problems at the micro side as well 
and you will be able to find out as soon as you get into mid game. 
The Good Side
[list]
[*]Super flashy, fast paced, highly responsive combat style.
[*]Lots, and Lots of unique classes and variants for you to find a class that suits you.
[*]Some late game items are account-bond which you can switch between characters.
[*]Lots of end game content, leveling is fairly fast with events.
[*]Events in game are one by one, never ending, you will always get something from it.
[*]Most of pay to win items can be bought from others with in-game gold.
[*]Devs dish out updates fairly fast with fresh content/event.
[*]2.5D anime graphic, seriously who doesn't love anime.
[/list]
The Bad Side
[list]
[*]Combats specially in late games are super punishing, a single wrong move can ruin the entire raid runs.
[*]There is a huge gap between top tier classes and others, balancing issue is huge, you might get blocked from end-game content just because you class is bottom tier.
[*]Daily activities that give late-game content items(tickets, currency. etc) give so less compares to what a character need so you will have to create a lots of alts if you really want to progress a lot faster.
[*]You will spend majority of your time stuck in mid-game, since the end-game gear requires lots of luck and resources. most of the time you will find you self stuck with grinding last piece of the set.
[*]The power level between gears are huge, end game gear set bonus are way too strong compared to pieces, which means 6 pieces of a set might do 100x if not more than 5. just because of it's 6 set bonus. 
[*]Pretty much every in-game activities, including gear progression, enhance, amplify etc cost plenty amount of currency, which means, lots of grinding.
[*]Most of the event's rewards gets pointless once you reached mid-game.
[*]New gears that come with updates are stronger most of the time, most of the gear from last patch loses it's value quickly. 
[*]Where is Project BBQ?
[/list]

I played hundreds of hours of this game long before it came to steam and while the current version has the most content there are too many issues for me to recommend it in good faith. 84005573.review:
[h1]Do not play DFO through Steam![/h1]
[b]I highly recommend playing this game on their official client outside of steam.[/b] A lot of people have complained that their accounts have been disabled before even finishing the client download on steam and other issues when purchasing cash shop items, if your account does get banned, I suggest making a ticket, their response is slow unfortunately but they will work with you. 
 
DFO is the highest grossing PC game of 2018 (According to Super Data) beating PC powerhouses such as World of Warcraft and League of Legends. You have not heard of this game mainly because many of its player base is from the East. 
 

[h1]On to the review:[/h1]
I do not recommend this game on steam but [b]I highly suggest checking it out through their official client.[/b] With its newer brothers on the horizon (Project BBQ and DnF Duel) it will be worth to check out and learn the lore before the new games come out. This MMO is very niche, not everyone likes side scrollers or pixelated graphics. Check it out you might like it. 
 
The game is a lot of fun doing flashy combos in multiple different dungeons with the 16 different classes in the game and 63 different advancements (Not including their 1st, 2nd, and NEO Awakenings which are just upgrades), the game is an eastern MMO meaning of course classes are gender locked but there are male and female equivalents for except 6 classes in the game and some advancements are not duplicated for its male or female equivalent this could be a plus or a negative for some players. There is no character customization upon creating a character which is a bummer, but gear will change your look same with cosmetic cash shop items which are mediocre at best. 
 
The gameplay in my personal experience gets boring mainly because side scrollers are not entirely my cup of tea what makes up for the boring gameplay is the class you play; flashy skills animations carry this game it looks great with this art style. The lore in DFO is solid I am not a big story person even more in MMO's but DFO did not disappoint me with its lore I suggest trying it when playing the game and search up more about the story it has a lot of potential and hopefully its subsidiary does its justice when it releases. I did not socialize personally in DFO but I have not seen the chat move with conversations like other games I cannot give my opinion but parties, trading, emails, and guilds do exist. 
 
There is a fatigue system I personally see this as a plus because it gives me reason to take break for the day, early on when your power leveling it will slow you down but once you play the game longer the more it gets brushed off. Early on the game feels a little bit outdate and boring but it starts getting better after you choose your sub class (In most occasions, some classes have extremely difficult or boring early games). The late makes up for the early game the animations are flashy enough to keep my attention as I said before but make sure you learn the game early on or you are going to have a rough time if you rush through, oh and there is a lot of events to help players. 
 
[h1]Is it Pay to Win?[/h1]
Short Answer: Yes | Long Answer: [b]No[/b] 
The reason the short answer is yes is mainly because when you pay in DFO, you pay to save time just like in games like BDO its more of a convenience or speed up factor and it also includes luck meaning a lot of it is RNG based (So you could lose money). To the extent that to get a return of "investment" you will need to spend thousands (This is regard of getting Epic gear, Legendary and Unique is more than enough to participate in end-game content). Everything in the game is farmable and with time you will be able to obtain everything but it will be a grind so be prepared there are a bunch of events that will boost you. Do not let what I said discourage you it is not as bad as you think way better than other MMO's *cough* Black Desert *cough*. 

[h1]6/10[/h1]
It is a solid game do not let steam player numbers discourage you most of the player base if off steam, but if you want a large community try playing the Korean or Chinese version of the game if you can get your hands on it. Great game to just sit back and relax with all the intense effects going on the screen.

83460106.review:
¿Es un korean grinder? Sin duda 
¿Es un MMOBeat 'em up? También
¿Es divertido? Mucho

Si no te lo tomas como un segundo trabajo (cosa clásica de estos juegos coreanos) es MUY divertido. Es el MMO en el que más me ha gustado el sistema de clases y subclases: 16 y 59 respectivamente. Grosso modo, puedes jugar entre otras cosas, como boxeador, bruja, mago, inquisidor, caballero, invocador, ingeniero, asesino, francotirador, samurai, luchador de lucha libre e incluso puedes ir de Naruto por la vida (Kunoichi, puedes sacar hasta un sapo gigante) o Goku (Nen Master, con kames y todo). La cantidad de clases es absurda. 

El juego es flashy as fuck, pero literal. Esto quiere decir que si eres fotosensible estás jodido (la guinda sería que se pudiera rebajar el nivel de destellos). Hay una cantidad abrumadora de habilidades que van escalando en nivel de absurdez hasta el punto en que algunos finishers parecen invocaciones del Final Fantasy. 

Tiene un modo historia realmente largo, tiene raids y tiene PVP. Como el nivel máximo de personaje es 100 y hay puntos de fatiga que te capan cuanto puedes jugar a diario con un mismo personaje (just korean things), hay juego para rato. 

Cosas malas:

- Los personajes son clónicos, cambiando solo la apariencia de las armas (y evidentemente según la clase que hayas cogido). Si quieres ir a lo "fashion DFO" te toca apoquinar pasta o gastar divisas muy limitadas que obtienes jugando. 

- No tiene compatibilidad directa con gamepad. Hay gente que ha hecho algunos apaños para poder jugarlo pero es durillo de configurar. Una pena porque le vendría como anillo al dedo. Al final te acostumbras al teclado pero que vas a aporrear todas las teclas como un descerebrado cuando empieces a jugar, es un hecho. Todos con artrosis de aquí a un tiempo. 

- Nunca he tenido problemas de conexión pero solo nos toca (en occidente) dos servidores, ambos en América. Podría darle problemas a alguien. 

- Tiene un sistema anti-hacking durísimo hasta el punto en que mucha gente se ha visto baneada o con las capacidades de tradeo/crafting capadas sin razón aparente pero que suele ser fruto de programas de terceros/overlays que dan falsos positivos. Esto quizás sea la peor parte ya que te obliga a abrir un ticket (en inglés) al servicio técnico y esperar a que te respondan. 


No es un juego perfecto pero es divertido y es único en su clase, no hay un MMO igual. Si te interesa pruébalo que es gratis.

82213877.review:
Okay, so I've been playing this since the PAX 2009 convention, so all my hours are from the original launcher.   I love the game genre, and I've played this game for many years.  That said, this game is an absolute tragedy.  
   
   Some of the good: The diversity of class mechanics are super fun, and awakening usually makes classes even funner.  The graphic, though dated, have particular charm to them for those like myself who like old school Arcade games.  Combat is super sharp and responsive, and overall just feels good.  Unlike the older days a respec for your character no longer cost $18 a pop, and can be done anytime, as many times as you want.  Getting an upgrade on your equipment is super impactful and feels great to be OP for a little while.
   
   The rest of the bad: This game definitely has no shortage of short comings, and I don't really feel like I have all day to name them all, so I just go though some of the more glaring ones.  Starting off with the most obvious issue that white knights will defend out of ignorance is the Fatigue point system.  It's basically a game play limiter a kin to many mobile games. Many of my friends stop playing because of this, and so did an imperial crap-ton of players. Imagine if a game like Diablo 3/4 did some shit like that. "Hey I know your been enjoying the Barbarian class cus it's the only class you really enjoy, but you can either make another one and start over, play a different class you don't like, or just stop playing, sound good?" I don't think Diablo 3 would even be running if they did that, but since a large portion of DFO players are dumb and irresponsible kids, they actually voted to keep FP when it made a return. 

   Next up is the most ridiculous rng, this is the shite that nightmare fuel is made of.  In short, you can play for a year straight and never even come close to completing an epic set, soooo hope you don't like progression THAT much.  Have fun trying to gear out all 10 to 20 or so of your characters for the rest of your life.  

   I'm not even going to get into PVP really cus it's busted AF, and probably always will be.  

   The cash shop is pretty abusable, and a bit predatory.  

   Content feels kinda slow, so instead Neople just releases a new class every couples years or so, and it works like a charm. (kinda like Warframe except slower)  

   And finally the cherry on this turd sundae is the customer service/support. It's not quite as bad as the days of Nexon NA, but it's still pretty bad. 

  *Fingers crossed* that one day a really solid company comes along with a good online arcade beat'em-up and puts this one down like a dog.

79244714.review:
On Steam I have 9 hours, Off Steam I have clocked over 500+ hours

This is not your typical pay-to-win game, this is your typical pay-to-progress game. If you don't plan on spending money. Don't bother with this game. It don't cost a penny to get to level up, however once you get into late game gear grinds that's where the real struggle begins. Yes, the game is intentionally constructed in this manner. Leveling a character is the easiest part of the game, in fact, from level 1 to level 95 is considered tutorial, where you get extra experiences from monster and bosses and follows a particular path for dungeons. 

All in all, if you don't plan on investing thousands of hours, years and years, or half of your paycheck. You aren't going to get very far in this game. The late game gear grind will not be kind to you.

However, if you enjoy playing video games and don't mind it being turned into a daily chore, or have to reset your gear progress every time they increase the level cap, and your wallet is as thick as your skull. This shall be the game for you.

I played the game once and hours later I was banned. I was not sure why, so I Googled it and there was a thread on a forum for the game and people were saying that it was a very common issue. People get banned because the company's anti-cheat detection system is very aggressive and will pick up false-positives on third-party software running on the background of your PC. The only other two apps I had open were Discord and Afterburner. 

Typically, something like this would not be an issue for me, but the REAL problem is that you have to reach out to their customer support, explain the issue, and have it unbanned and can take a some unpleasant length of time. 

The game itself is pretty good and I would consider moving forward with putting in a ticket, but I simply do not want this to be a recurring issue if I end up really enjoying this game. It is for this exact reason that I cannot recommend the game.

77583073.review:
First off, I played this Pre-Neople and I also am going to say dont play this on Steam and go to their site itself to get it because i've noticed that a majority of the negative reviews for this game is from getting banned through steam. I guess it flags your account for some reason? Also this is highly enjoyable with a friend, but being a solo player is still fine.

Anyway on to the actual game review.
PvE
DFO pre-neople had fun combos that felt very fluid and let you really smack around any mob that wasnt rooted to the floor and Im happy to say that it is still just that. Knowing your skills and getting to infinitely juggle a mob is pretty fun to me. I had well over 1000hrs on this game pre-neople because i loved the combat in it so much and as i already said, they havent really changed it. Instead i got to come back to many new class upgrades along with new skills that just got to make your combos flashy and have some really dope combo ending moves. The equipment is a grind to make sure you get good gear through various methods (hell mode, raids, events, etc . . .), but by doing the MSQ in the game you'll be properly equipped to get through it to max level. Unfortunately I cant comment on if the story itself is great because i beat it a while ago and my 20+ other characters i have were just rushed through it to get their class skills and whatnot. The "early game" is rather boring because it feels pretty watered down compared to pre-neople and from what ive seen thats not just my opinion as a pre-neople player. In the beginning a lot of your skills are going to do a ton of damage and you'll wipe rooms of mobs in probably 10-20 seconds (Including the bosses), but once you get past level 40 it starts to pick up and the enemies become sturdier, but they're still not very challenging (I just wanted to mention this because the game does pick up and getting to level 40-50 is very easy by just doing the msq, If an event is going you can accomplish this in a day. If there's no event, but you're burning your FP gauge everyday itd probably take 3 days). After that you'll reach the meat of the game with your awakening for your class giving you your first ULT skill and you'll have plenty of class specific skills to play around with. 

Side Note* the game feels like a ghost town in lower level areas. I dont know if the PB is dwindling or if there's a lack of new players in general, but most of the lower levels you'll encounter are just alts for people who already have a stacked level 90-100 character. Please do not let that push you away as i really like the game and would love to have new players running around as i level alts. Helping is always fun.

PvP
Pre-neople the reason i had over 1000 hrs was because of pvp. If any returning player saw this post and actually decided to read it for some reason, they might recognize my OG soul reaper name "RadiantGhost". I was constantly in lobbies pvping everyone i could. The reason i bring this up is because this is really my only critique that i have towards the game now. I used to love DFO's pvp, so when i returned on its relaunch day and got my soul reaper back to level 50 i immediately hopped into the pvp channels. got to play a few games and it felt . . . different. It didnt feel as smooth as it was before and honestly it made me angry enough to stop doing it since. I need to go back and try it out again, but for some reason in PvE everything is great and fluid and nothing feels out of sync or delayed. PvP doesnt either, but it seemed like a lot of the time things weren't registering or connecting. i might have just gotten a bunch of matches with people with poor internet, but the game seemed like it was running fine (No rubber banding, de-sync, or anything else)  
 
TL;DR combo things, use dope skills that are nice and flashy. Then PvP
7.5/10 (Id give it a 9 if i didnt think the intro to the game was so . . . easy.)

So what do we have so far? 

Awesome, already 1.2 hours playtime and I had not the chance to play the game a single time. 
The login in the launcher does not work automatically. 
I guess, the port between Steam and DFO does not work as intended.
Contacting the Neople support makes me feel there is no support. 
I put some time and effort into this project and the result was ... waste of time. 
About the game: I can not really review this game, maybe its good who knows.

This game has progressed a long, long way since its days when nexon shut it down originally. Most classes are great, have a good amount of flash and substance, and they let you play around with skills and character advancements early. They really made it an easier way to play. And they added a ton of polish and work in the story to the point its not a garbled mess.

But the immediate trade restriction ruined the game almost immediately for new people. Not being able to trade is a huge road block for playing this game long term. I know it was place to stop bots, but they are shooting themselves in the foot by chocking out any new player base thats coming in.

73499093.review:
This really is a great game. Dungeon Fighter Online is an Arcade Brawler MMO, those games you played as a kid at the arcades? This is it in mmo form. There are MANY classes to choose from it would take ages just to describe them all.  I personally Favor the Indra subclass of the Slayer. He's a blind swordsman who uses elemental slashes, its pretty gnarly. This game has something for everybody. This biggest issue you'll find in DFO is that character cosmetics cost real money, or a fuck load of in game gold, most classes have 1 or 2 sets you can just kinda get by playing the game cosmetic wise, but few of them are really any good. 
           The second and most glaring issue with DFO is the Fatigue System. The Fatigue system is basically a time limit on how long you can play that specific character that day, run enough dungeons to drain your fatigue and you can't play that character anymore until daily reset unless you have a hold of a fatigue potion that can restore some points. All in all this game heavily incentivises making alt characters but that's not really a bad thing, Pick this game up and give it a go imo.

73125037.review:
This game is hard to get into at first, but if you do manage to figure it out and get far enough into it, you will find a rewarding game that is a blend of fighting game/dungeon crawler/MMORPG. 
Pros:
Fun late game
Unique Classes
Flashy Anime Style
Fighting Game style Combos (if you play as a combo character)
Constant Events to help new players level and veterans get gear/Cosmetics/Grind Skip
Cons:
Extremely easy early game.
Some classes dont start feeling really good until level 40.
Slight Pay to Win (cosmetics give minor stat increases, but can be bought with ingame gold)
Complex and Hidden systems that can take some time to understand.

Overall a Solid game, with an enjoyable combat system and unique flavor in a MORPG. I highly recommend giving it a shot, but find someone to play with, preferably one who knows the game already.

70321100.review:
So start off DFO or Dungeon Fighter Online in 2020 is still a game that has so much to do in it. Tho I really hate their FATIGUE system which stops me as a under lev X player from crunching my time and getting to max level. I would recommend they change it so that if my level is under 70 (so I get to 2nd Awakening)  make it so my Fatigue points won't drop so that if I have 15h to spend this Saturday in the game I may do it.  
Honestly I try to find out more con's but other than the Fatigue system I can't think of anything right now, I just got to lev 50 in 3 days which is not a long time thinking that you have 156 Fatigue points which translates to 156 areas of the dungeon you can explore.  
A thing the game does not tell you : If you start a dungeon with 1FP (fatigue point ) you can clear it and get normal XP but then the following one is closed and you have to return to town. 
Combat is flashy and I can't believe there are many PC's that can't run this at Ultra as it's mostly sprites but so well done they are just eye candy. 
Classes and the outstanding amount of uniqueness each sub-class has makes me just want to level each Character to max level as I have a lot of favorites .
TL:DR : 
PRO : 
Lots of flashy action, lots of things to do, lots of characters that play different so I find it impossible you can't find your play style.
CONS : Fatigue system should be disabled if you are a new player/want to crunch those hours so you can get to lev 70

70052717.review:
Edit (July 2022): Tried to come back to this game, but to my surprise (not) there are a few concerns.

One, they REFUSE to delete personal information upon request.  They "deactivate" the account and assure "your personal information is safe".  This is explicitly ILLEGAL in both the USA and S. Korea, according to the e-CFR and PIPA respectively, so they have no excuse.

Two, subsequently, you won't be able to unlink the account associated with your Steam account.  They refuse to unlink it; they'll just "deactivate" it.  So you won't be able to play.

Three, in their Privacy Policy they explicitly state they reserve the right to scan your computer for "malicious software".  It still puts up false flags that plague Steam users to this day, obvious privacy concerns aside.

Shady, shady company.  Steer clear if you care about privacy.

*~~~~~~~~*

You cannot use your Neople account on the Steam version.  This means you need to create a fresh account to play on Steam.

Not a problem for me, I wanted a fresh account.  I go on my Neople account, change the main email address on there, and try to use the main email to verify my Steam account.

Doesn't work.  Now both the original email and the new email I swapped my Neople account to cannot be used.

So I message support to get it fixed.  No response, but a day later my Steam account has been "Blocked by an administrator."  (This issue has been in the Steam version for months.  Literally since launch.)

I message them again, and they respond within an hour say they have trouble finding my Steam account under the provided email, ignoring the fact that I told them I was never even able to complete that step in the first place.  Regardless, I promptly message them the information they requested.

It's been days and I still haven't heard back from them.  It's almost been a week and I still can't play this game.

This is nothing short of sheer incompetence.

Edit:  They finally unblocked my account.  They're implying that this happened because I have "malicious 3rd party programs on my computer".  I'm sure all the people who have had this problem has a very specific virus whose only function is to block your DFO account.  Yes, that sounds plausible.  /s  This is possibly concerning considering this may imply they're scanning your files.

Oh, and they couldn't fix the email conflict.  "... once an Email address has been used to register a DFO Account, it will no longer be available for use again."  No reason given.  What a joke.

68865709.review:
I have played this game on Korean server since 2010 before they blocked international IP from them; some may say this game is no longer like it was before (it's true, but games need to evolve in order to survive sometimes), and that it requires you to spend real money on it eventually. I would have to disagree: some features likes raid and such yes, but for simply enjoying the game, I think it has many events going on at the same time, most of the time, so spending money really isn't necessary. You can just enjoy the game for what it is: story line, attractive characters, and the reason that I come back -- the satisfying hitting sensation on the tip of your fingers (Koreans call it 타격감 or 손맛). 

All in all, I would wholeheartedly recommend it. I couldn't always play it because you know, life, but I also keep on coming back to it not only because of nostalgia, but because I know for a fact that it just feels so satisfying to combo and to shred the mobs in the dungeons. Not to forget, this game is an MMORPG, but you can definitely ignore literally everyone and play on your own if you wanted to -- I personally think that's a huge perk!

67645689.review:
This game was fun for me only because of one reason: The grappler class.

A while back, I was looking for side-scrolling brawler to waste time on and I found this on Steam. It was free and it seemed fine so I tried it out. I chose the female fighter class because all I wanted to do was punch things. After playing the tutorial and taking a look at the skills, I learned about the Diva subclass where all you do is grapple enemies. OK. That normally wouldn't be a big deal, but then I learned you can tornado-cyclone quadruple backwards German suplex 30 unsuspecting cultists into the [i]FUCKING[/i] [b]DIRT[/b] only to pick them up and do it again, permanently imprinting their faces into the temple floors.

Holy crap.

I played until my character hit max cap just because the feeling of somersaulting through the air while carrying 23 motorcyclists (and their motorcycles) and crashing into the ground with the explosive strength of the Tsar Bomba only to immediately combo into a gorilla press strong enough to create an earthquake is something you can't really replicate in other games. This is made even better by the fact that most bosses aren't immune to grabs, so you can string together a series of suplexes and slams until you disintegrate your enemies into a mass of indescribable matter.

Story is whatever, translations are trash, voice acting is all Korean, the cash shop is disgusting, nobody likes to talk, but honestly who cares about those things. The controls are solid, there are tons of levels, the graphics are nice, and you can break down your enemies into their base elemental components via piledrivers and guillotine drops.

Do yourself a favor and at least try it. Skip the cutscenes, skip the quests, pick the female fighter and just go nuts. 
Trust me.

60632580.review:
Negatives:

1)  Main problem to me is that when you download and install the game nobody ever mentions that if you play through Steam you are f-ed if you want to buy cera (premium in-game currency). And depending on your class or goals, you may desperately need cera. Be warned that if you play through Steam, there is a high chance to be banned, trade-locked, or purchase-locked for no reason. Play through the official site if you will be playing. 
2)  The game security requirements are ridiculous. I am sitting here with my phone in my hand because I receive a password on my phone every time I want to log in or unlock item that I want to sell. They don’t discriminate between the Chinese market and US market and apply the same bs rules for purchasing and account security based on all the scams stemming from China.
3) The game runs heavy and is WAY too big for a 2D game. There is a lot, roughly 1/3rd, of "dead content" that is not employed by anyone and serves no purpose because it's outdated. The materials and gear dropped from those dungeons are useless, therefore they should have been removed once they became so outdated instead of allowing the game to be so heavy (and those dungeons also confuse new players and waste your time).
4)  A large portion of your success depends on relentless grind on mini-games inside the main game. By mini-games, imagine tetris or snake-like games, which reward you gear, pets, avatars, and materials. You are free to pass on those, but you will fall behind significantly compared to other people because those games offer great benefits.
5)  Updates are too often, every two weeks (religiously), and are mostly dedicated to the aforementioned mini-games, which are changed with a new one with every update (these are so called "events"). Those updates sometimes take up to 30 min to finish and if your connection just gets a tiny disturbance - the launcher shuts down on you and you need to start all over.
6)  New players will mandatory be completely lost. Your only guide in this game is the first 5 min to learn to punch, jump, and move with arrows. Disassembling, extracting, refining, amplifying, enchanting, compounding, alchemy, puppeteering,  avatar dying, gear retexturing, level range for party, at what level bellow you creatures stop giving exp, what are the pros and cons of all those 60 classes – all things for you to figure out the hard way.
7)  All female characters’ appearances are bland and technically the same thing –half naked, pale young girls. There is really no armor or even remote resemblance to warriors or toughness in any of them.
8)   The repair system is merciless. Get hit 3 times and spend 20k gold on repairs, thus ending up the dungeon on a loss. It doesn't make sense that durability fix from 38 to 40 cost like 15k gold.

Positives:

1)	You are allowed to create many characters on the same account, so you won’t be limited if you want to try many classes.
2)	Community on Discord is very helpful.
3)	Graphics that will satisfy retro-seeking experience similar to beat them-up arcade games.
4)	Some end game boss fights are similar to old Nintendo bosses where you need to figure out their gimmicks and pattern before you can effectively tackle them, which make it a similar and nostalgic experience.
5)	I myself have not experienced major bugs or glitches. I lost materials twice, for whatever reason, but I was compensated by the administration.
6)	There is satisfying amount of things to do once you reach max level – farm materials and gold, beat top level bosses, develop your explorer club, collect max level character classes, level up your profession, grow your guild, level up your rank.
7)	Skill reset is free.

60410776.review: I am giving the game a yes for recommending but I have been with this game before Neople ever got a hold of it. (Day one) The game is Definitely a RNG Korean style grinding MMO. For those of you who don't know what that is, you will spend weeks into months GRINDING at end game. That is the con of this game. The pro is that there are tons of classes and each has 3-4 subclasses inside that are unique to the class. They definitely is a huge variety for every play style. It is F2P but P2progress/win sort of. It uses a stamina based system which for you MMO junkies means you will have to stop eventually. But I find this game addicting and it helps me limit my time so I can have a real life. Worst case scenario, you make alts (you can have up to like 20+ so if you don't want to stop, you don't have to.) Events are rampant in this game and some (as of currently) super boost a lv 1 character to end game in just 3 days with all end game gear. This saves literal months of grinding. (Kind of a cheap out if you ask me because my main isn't even close to my new characters gear...<_<... BUT HEY, now i can use my "alt main" to grind items for my main to gear up faster!) PvP is fun but can be frustrating as it is a P2P connection. PvE to level is mind numbingly easy with end game content being challenging where you do have to learn fights and what to look out for as most bosses will one shot you regardless of gear. Overall, a grindy, unique sidescrolling combat game that has been my serious, and casual MMO that I have enjoyed seeing evolve into an actual good fleshed out game. (You should have seen the atrocity it was when Nexon had it....omg i threw this in the trash.) Ever since Neople though, it's been enjoyable.

59553706.review:
Very well made game that can almost be described as Diablo 2: Side-scrolling Beat em up edition.
Looks simple on the surface but possesses some extremely complex mechanics underneath.
DFO plays like a classic fighting game with throws, grapples, back-dashes, animation cancels and even displays enemies health like a fighting game opponent bar. Throw in a complex mmo style gear system with tiered armour, unique weapons, enchantments crafting and some truly strange professions that range from the mundane like enchanting and weapon-smithing to the bizarre like puppet making or sewing.
Did I mention this game has 40 man raid instances? And that its a side scrolling beat -em-up?
Play this game, you wont be disappointed.

59500304.review:
So here we go, I saw some stuff about this game and it looked like the best game for me, I love flashy combat, big AoE abilities etc, grinding for my stuff, my gear etc..

And then I started playing...

At first I liked it, but o man, what is it with Korean game developers, and creating amazing games and adding these ridiculously bad mechanics and systems to it, ruining the fun, and going full on for the money!

[b] Let's start with the Fatique Points (FP) system: [/b]
So when u create a character, and u start playing, u do quests and mostly clear dungeons.
Now the thing is, for every dungeon u clear or every room u clear in a dungeon, it uses up some FP.

Now your max FP will be 156 (273 with premium, but we'll get to that later) and u basicly use around 8 FP per dungeon.

So let's say u played for about 3-4 hours on your first character, you're out of FP and u gotta wait a day to play again, or u create a new character, cous FP isn't account bound, but character bound.

[b] Which leads to the next topic, alts: [/b]
You are basicly forced to create more than 1 character to actually make this game your main game, u either play a few hours and come back the next day, or u play around 3+ characters atleast to get the most out of this game.

Now when u finally got that max level character, you found your main, you love the class, great!
You ready to grind for your gear? alright, well, let's get some legendaries, so basicly now u go to a town called "Harlem", and in that town, u can start a dungeon which is called "Assault", which u can do 3 times, and then u get a bonus dungeon, which u do once, and boom, you're done for the day! (PS: This takes around 30 minutes to complete!)

After u got your full Harlem legendary set, u go for Epics, to get epics, u basicly upgrade your Harlem Legendaries into Epics by doing a dungeon called "Dawning Crevice", which u can do twice a day.... and you're done.

So basicly u do your daily dungeons on your main, and boom, you're done for the day! now do that for a couple months and u got full Epics!

Wait so you're limited on how much u can play? YES!
You can't just keep running dungeons over and over, do different dungeons for different goals? NOPE

You can however, do a dungeon called "Operation Hope" which u can do 3 times a day to get legendary gear pieces which are called "Swap Set" gear pieces, u can put these gear pieces in a seperate section of your gear, to buff your buff skill.

So after running that 3 times, you're basicly done again.

Now the thing is with the Swap Set gear pieces, you equip them in a seperate section, but, they will still stay in your inventory, so u have a reason to purchase inventory slots...

[b] Now on to Neo Premium: [/b]
Basicly u want more than 156 FP, u can buy Neo Premium to up that number to 273 FP, but watch out, you got 2 different types of Neo Premium!
One of them is basicly useless and the other one gives the FP boost and some other decent things.

So u decide u actually like the game, and want to play more on each character by buying Neo Premium?
RIP! u can't cous u first need to complete end-game content before your account will be unlocked and u can buy Neo Premium! CYA IN A FEW MONTHS OF PLAYING A COUPLE HOURS A DAY DOING THE SAME SHIT WHICH U COMPLETE IN ABOUT 2 HOURS A DAY!

[b] More shit... [/b]
Did I mention there's a chance your account gets banned right after u created it? Yep, that's right, your account has a chance of just getting banned right after creation for no reason when u play it on steam, then u gotta contact Neople's support, send in a ticket and wait for their response...

Also, u use spacebar or your left mouse button to talk to NPC's but apparently the spacebar is bugged sometimes and u gotta use the mouse click (80% of the time for me...), but there's a player in front of the NPC! well rip, go change channel so u can click on the NPC!

Honestly, korean game developers mentallity of creating a game is so fcking unlogically weird to me.

It feels to me like they actually want to create an insanely good game, and then when the game is done, they are like WAIT!! first we add some insanely annoying mechanics, add a shit ton of limitations to the player, which they gotta pay for to stretch out a bit, and limit them on the amount of dungeons u can do daily not only cous of the FP system but also on the actual amount u can do the dungeons u gotta do to progress....

I can keep going for hours on how much I love koreans games fundamentally, but just completely do NOT understand what goes on in the minds of these people when it comes to implementing these insanely annoying, P2W mechanics.

TL;DR: This game is full of annoying mechanics, limitations and unlogical decisions made by the developer to grab some cash and lock the fun behind stupid P2W shit.

I can actually keep going, but I geus this shit is long enough.... please don't play this game.

57780757.review:
Great Game, reminds me of arcade beat em up / street fighter combined into an awesome RPG format. Some stuff will feel dated, especially if you are a younger gamer, but there is a lot of polish to this game, and honestly its pretty painless to climb to max level. Ive been back 8 days and almost hit max level, which is where you will find most people grouping and raiding. Community is helpful (when i was streaming the chat had lots of advice).

PROS:
Fast, Action-Oriented  Fighting/RPG Game Style
Amazing Music Scores: electronic/rock style with occasional vocals.
Tons of replayability, lots of classes and perks to leveling multiple characters.
Very Satisfying to pull off a lengthy combo on a boss mob.

CONS:
Not a big PVP Community if thats your thing, game is not balanced around it, but they did just host a yearly tournament I viewed, fun to watch.
Initial learning curve can be daunting, ask for help on forums or check youtube.
Clunky UI, needs a major overhaul.

Video scaling leaves a lot to be desired, graphics desperately need higher resolutions for modern day gaming.
Low level gameplay is fun to learn on, but no real challenges arise. The game is centered around reaching level 95, so you have time to practice a lot of your abilities and figure out your class while you grind to 95.

Pay-To-Win Shop. Honestly this doesn't bother me that much because this game is more about having fun reaching end game and polishing your character.  I haven't spent a dime but already am chomping at the bits to start lvl95 gameplay.

Newer Classes are clearly favored over many older classes. Some are ridiculously overtuned and just dwarf their equivalent(i am still a newb so maybe someone can correct me, dark knight = best traits of all slayer classes?) for example.

Overall I'm giving the game 3.5 out of 5. I think they can definitely make this game greater with all their income from the p2w shop, i know there has to be a lot of addicts forking over a small fortune on this game. Give the people the best possible product in 2019! Tune up older classes, polish up the UI and graphics, and maybe hire a few more folks so your not stuck on a endless cycle of just creating new end game content, classes, and items for your shop.

-Cheers

An old, but fun game. The grind has gotten significantly more tolerable over the years. Reaching endgame is now a reasonable goal. The community is fairly friendly, many of them still around from the old days. There's a crazy amount of classes to choose from as well, so you'll always have variety.

55869221.review:
I've been paying DFOG for a few years on and off.  While the game at its core  is extremely fun, the end game grind is repetitive and lengthy (also does not reward much for the amount of work/effort one puts in). 

You have dailies, and weeklies. With the latter being more important, but it takes so long to get gear it's almost pointless. Not to mention the needlessly complex the gearing has to be...just to be "raid-worthy". Need good title? 8-10m gold. Good aura? easily 20+mil. Advanced avatar? 5-8m. Decent pet? 10m+.

And all of this is MANDATORY for end-game raiding. Not to mention enhancements, and avatar emblem slots...easily another 10m. 

So all together you're looking at about 50m+ for possible viable end game. Oh and need min +10 weapon which can cost you another 30m-50m alone. This is just the top of my head so I might be missing a few more things too. 

All of this is for ONE character. The good thing, however, is that the devs have events on and off that helps to facilitate this process--so I'll give them that. Overall though, the community isn't "elitist" like most people think. There are just hard cut-offs and if you don't have (at minimum) what I just described, good luck getting into a decent group.

Lastly, the game is fairly dead, with scraps of active guilds here and there. I think the game would be a ton better with even a little more population but this game does not appeal to the Western market.

54546612.review:
Dungeon Fighter Online, DFO, es un juego scrolling 2D de Acción con un corazón de MMORPG. Este juego tiene un guiño a los juegos de la vieja escuela, como Golden Axe, y nos hará sentir un sentimiento retro único. Tenemos cientos de mapas por descubrir y miles de enemigos que derrotar. Tiene una opción PvP muy interesante y es un buen juego para los amantes del 2D scroll..

En Dungeon Fighter Online podremos encontrar 6 clases que a partir de nivel 18 podremos especializar en varias clases avanzadas. En total hay más de 30 clases avanzadas con las que podremos aventurarnos tanto en PvE como en PvP.

54516359.review: Interested in trying an accessible and fun f2p mmorpg? Then give this game a shot! The combat and grind are very satisfying, even after long play sessions. The game has great structure from a gameplay and administrative perspective. Honestly, the thing that sets this mmo in particular apart from others in the current market is that it provides a pleasant experience you can enjoy without feeling pressured to empty your wallet on the cash shop. I'm looking forward to spending more time with DFO. Great job Neople, please continue to improve the consumer friendly monetization and awesome gameplay DFO has to offer!

54509879.review:
I used to enjoy playing this game. But it seems the people who produced and host it no long maintain or manage it intelligently. I came back after hearing about new classes and went to download the obscene number of files I needed for the update. After that, I booted the game and it loaded in a strange, off center position; the center of the screen for the game was in the lower right corner of my monitor. I shrugged it off; I had just downloaded a lot of stuff, so I figured it was just because if that. Trying to reboot it caused it to refuse to even load past the launcher; it just instantly shut off.

Then a friend of mine contacted me on Steam and told me the game had become a virus. I went and checked my Malwarebytes and sure enough, it had kicked in just after I had given the go ahead to download the updates. So now the game won't start because the site it's connecting to to run it is registered as malware. Did they really allow this to happen to their game, or was it done on purpose by the company?

I give this game a huge thumbs down. Do NOT try to install this or if you like me are coming back, don't even bother. If it's registering as malware (it didn't used to do this with the same software installed) then something's gone wrong. I'll be uninstalling this immediately and reporting it to Valve to see if they'll investigate it further. It's too bad too; the game used to be pretty good.

54170413.review:
Don't even know where to begin with this game. It's so unique and diverse in terms of what character you can play. One of it's main drawing points is the fact that is has over 50 different classes (yes, 50, not a typo) to choose from, all with vastly different play-styles.

I've played it since the dark ages of Nexon, to now it's far more successful, active and hard-working team that has nearly brought it up to speeds with it's Korean counter-part (this game is HUGE over there btw) and continue to work to keep it updated as Korea continues to pump out new content and ever more classes.

The effects for nearly all the skills (except some of the base skills from 1- 15) are animated very well. The combat is fast-paced with the ability to cancel into attacks, cancel into back dashes to move into other attacks if necessary, great mobility skills on most classes and it's always satisfying to see the numbers fly across the screen and pull off a great combo and absolutely decimate a room or boss.

PvP is very intense as well with great measures taken to level the playing field between all the classes. I can't say more about it than that however as PvP just isn't my cup of tea. 

If you're a fan of "big-number" games like Maplestory or WoW (let's be honestly that's what it really is) or a fan of the old 2D pixelized graphics with addicting combat, you're missing out by not giving this game a try.

Fyi ~ my "hours played" means nothing, this isn't a paid review, I've always played directly through the launcher and never had a single problem with it. There are security measures in place to protect your account but speaking from personal experience, it is necessary.

53994923.review:
There's been a lot that's happened with this game in the transition from Nexon to Neople.  No less than two full story revisions and the return of pre-Neople Arad as the start of the game.  What a ride.  Don't mind my Steam hours - I have to play on Neople's own launcher since the Steam version of the game won't allow me to access my primary account.  My history with the game dates back to 2013.

For those who aren't familiar with the game, DFO is a side-scrolling, sprite-based anime-themed, fantasy beat-'em-up MMO.  I know that's a mouthful, but bear with me.  If you're familiar with Golden Axe, and Final Fight, you've got a good idea of what the combat plays like.  On top of its, it has the levels, skill-tree-system, and randomly-generated loot of something akin to Diablo 2.  Combat is simple to understand but can be very complex to master.  Mastering the game's combat means understanding some fighting-game-esque terminology, such as invulnerability frames (animations in which you cannot be hit), super armor (an effect that prevents you from flinching due to being hit), knockdown immunity, juggle combos (knocking an enemy into the air and hitting them repeatedly before they can land and stand up again), grappling (grabbing attacks that defeat Super Armor and interrrupt attacks) and grapple immunity (enemies that due to their size, strength, or being rooted to the ground, cannot be grappled).  Most of this will be familiar to anyone who's played an arcade-style beat-'em-up game before or a fighting game, and even if it sounds daunting, it's not that hard to pick up with a little practice.  The game gives you a training ground to do that practice in, too, with a wide variety of customizable training dummies with different behaviors to familiarize yourself on.

Thus far, I've been impressed with the additions of the Male Mage, Agent, Knight, Thief, and Demonic Lancer.  In particular, I like that Male Mage avoids the class bias that has afflicted other gendered classes, in that none of his subclasses - with one exception - cleanly mirror his female counterpart.  As a result, it doesn't invite easy comparison between the two.  These easy comparisons are something which has led to long-time stigmas against classes that have clearly-superior versions in one gender or another.

What I've not been impressed with is the fact that these gender biases have never been significantly addressed by Neople.  There are a number of classes where you are outright inferior than your counterpart, simply due to choice of gender.  Slayer, Fighter, Priest, and [i]particularly[/i] Gunner all suffer from this.  I really don't want these classes to be homogeneous - that would take away their unique identity.  I would like them to become comparably powerful but in unique ways, so that they don't invite such easy comparisons to one another.

Another big gripe I have is with the durability and repair system.  If you utilize cube skills heavily, or play a class that has to rapidly spam skills to reach peak effectiveness, your repair bills will be frankly obscene.  The entire end-card reward for a dungeon, as well as much of the gold you picked up during the dungeon or obtained by selling dungeon loot, can be eaten by repair bills, even if you haven't died or been hit much.  This punishes certain classes more than others, and forces them to deliberately play in subpar fashion just to avoid eating up all of their dungeon rewards with repair bills.  If you're on a class that isn't spammy and doesn't rely on cube skills to be effective, you're golden.

If you're a returning player from earlier in Neople's ownership of the game, chances are you're going to have to replay a lot of side quests that have been rolled into the mission system.  On the bright side, extra quest rewards, including free Halidom weapons (the replacement of old-school Legacy weapons).  On the not so bright side, you might have to retread some ground.  The progress of scenario quests has been kinda heavily abridged and reworked; these days, you'll typically spend less than seven runs in any given dungeon.  That could be good or bad depending on how you look at it - on one hand, the story suffers a bit from moving so fast, on the other hand, a lot of the early-game grind is flat-out gone.

Speaking of the new storyline, it's probably not important to a lot of people, but aside from its abridging, I like where it goes.  The Four Blademasters, the most common APC helpers you're given during the story, aren't the overpowering supercharacters they were previously - you can realistically expect to keep up with them in a fight if you play well.  It helps present the image that you stand with them as an equal, instead of just being a bystander while they save the day.  The story itself seems to reinforce this a lot too.  There's more exploration of the Metastasis and the Mirror World in this version, and they're a lot more clear on what the Metastasis actually [i]is[/i] this time around.  That said, the writing could use just a bit of polish - or at least a good copy editor.  I don't know if it's a problem with translating Korean pronouns or what, but the game frequently mis-genders minor charactes, and is sometimes inconsistent on character's titles or names.  It's minor, but a little bit irksome to me.

If you liked old Nexon DFO, but hate that they summarily got rid of old Arad and Hendon Myre, or you played Neople DFO but hated how indecisive they were about the nature of the Metastasis, the Apostles, and the world beyond the Black Nightmare, or you hated the early-game grind of either of the previous versions, you'll probably enjoy the game a lot more now.  If you preferred either of the original stories, or hate it when stories are abridged, or you just can't stand games with gender-class bias and janky durability and repair systems, you might want to give this a pass.  If you're a fan of side-scrolling beat-'em-ups in general, and would like to explore the idea of one as an MMO, DFO is not a bad choice for your first exposure to it.

53891530.review:
This is a fairly interesting game, ill be honest. Its just a shame what has happened to it.

I liked dungeon fighter online, but in its current state, its just not nearly as good as it was under nexon, which is saying something. 
The game as it is now is fairly difficult to actually get running as not only is the steam client seemingly not properly set up correctly but their security measures go so far as to actively hinder players attempting to play it. Amongst things ranging from overzealous security options that are not an option, requiring a six number code if you want to change account info such as passwords, which is then -required- to login with an implicit statement if you lose that in addition to your password, your account will be lost, to things ranging from an additional pin number, a region lock, a google authenticator as well as other such things, where they are outright expecting you to use all of these simultaneously. 

As well as a mixture of various other things, it took me far too long to get my account into a state I can play with it, before running into the game and realizing they kind of took away quite of the charm in the game. Its far..clunkier, far cringier. They went far too overboard on visual effects, they kind of shower you with experience and levels to such a quick degree that I never really felt...attached to the game or my characters and never really was given a long enough chance to master combos and other such.

It seems like...its mostly good intentions, but things like their security issues make me think that they have horrendous security in the first place and are trying to create a security theatre where their system is vulnerable while likely leaving the majority of players who want to check this out deciding to try something else that doesnt subject them through the hoops this puts you through. While the fast experience and growth seems like a way to quickly get progressing and unlocking subclasses and such, but it left me kind of breezing through areas without actually caring about the game or its new story it kind of shoved into existing areas.

It's very well polished side scrolling beat-em-up with the added layer of online multiplayer in the form of a cheap Asian-MMO. Controls are good for being keyboard only and the combat does feel arcade like, which I assume is the goal.

The RPG aspect is very light-weight so far (this may change as I approach the endgame), and that serves the game well. If you enjoy the good ole Double Dragons, Battletoads, Streets of Rages, and Golden Axes of yester-year, then you should like this one.

48727591.review: Dungeon Fighter Online is a classic 2D side-scrolling beat-'em up vaguely reminiscence of the old Street Fighter, only against mobs as opposed to one-versus-one duels. New players can easily be overwhelmed by the game's old school UI and showers of gifts - much of which won't be useful to the player until much later in the game. However, this a thoroughly enjoyable game if players are willing to look past the various quirks that stem from early 2000's top-of-the-line game design. After a decade of updates, additional content and patches, this game still ranks as one of the best free-to-play MMORPGs; a testimony to the game's highly enjoyable combat system and overall ingenious game design. Best played with a friend.

THE GOOD:
-Core gameplay is fun, classic beat em up style with RPG elements.

48374833.review:
Dungeon Fighter Online, ah a relatively great mmorpg and one I did enjoy quite a bit. It's interesting with some choices it make even if some are them are relatively bad choices.

The story makes no sense and is all over the place and they continue to add to the story I can't even think of a basic summary of it because its so nonsensical, but the story doesn't matter here. Every now and then they add a relatively new starting sequence of the game making it just more complicated. Its gotten to the point where I don't care at all for the story now with how complicated and nonsensical it is.

The gameplay is fun imo, its fun doing the combos and using the movement keys with the attack keys to activate skills which I enjoy. Though its sometimes wonky and might not even understand what you're trying to do, but that's common with systems lik this. Though the stamina system is stupid and NEVER should be implemented in ANY games whatsoever, I mean there was a QoL change that actually decreased how much stamina you used during a dungeon. This leads to the dungeoneering portion of Dungeon Fighter Online. It's relatively fine and dandy till you start getting to lvl 60+ in which is becomes grindy and sometimes unbalanced. There is a class system in this game which is like Elsword and most games like this, but it doesn't matter much.

The designing and look of the game is very animey which should be obvious from these type of games, if you're used to that design and look you probably know what to expect. If not, well it's gonna be really flashy and such. The weapons look relatively basic, so don't expect much.

In the end I do recommend this game, but that's mainly due to the QoL changes they have done. If those QoL changes never happened I might not of recommended this game, but this is just my opinion. Take it how you will, play what you want.

47684939.review:
[u]Overview[/u]

I have been playing Dungeon Fighter Online on and off since the days Nexon was officially providing its service. I enjoy the game still and even more so that its original developers picked it up to release globally. I appreciate the continous updates to which we are within a year behind Korea's content as well. The gameplay has always been the same and the ever growing cast of characters always brings something new to the repetitive, yet addictve grindfest for those sweet epics. Although leveling is much easier than ever before, many can vouch that it is but a beginning to the true game, its endgame content. Nonetheless, the game encourages you to play multiple alternative characters for stat bonuses and side content entries, which supports more gameplay despite the fatigue system ironically hindering your progress on any character you choose to main. Purchasing CERA(in-game cash) through a Steam account not being possible is perhaps the biggest deal breaker that could push potential players from downloading the Steam launcher and using it. 

I for one, use the NeoPle account, but launch the game from Steam by logging out in the launcher and logging in with the former. Albeit unorthodox, I still get to see my gaming hours, while being able to broadcast through steam. Achievements will be unavailable however, if those are something you wish to collect. 

[u] Pros [/u]
[list]
    [*] Storyrich
    [*] Consisting content updates
    [*] Published and serviced by original developers
    [*] Unique gameplay compared to other MMORPGs out there
    [*] Low-end, 10 year old hardware can run the game surprisingly well
    [*] Fun with friends and guilds have helpful micro communities
[/list]

[u] Cons[/u]
[list]
    [*] Fatigue system stops you from playing a character for the rest of the day
    [*] Grinding a repititve mode for drops is to be expected if you even want to breathe in a raid(which is end-game content)
    [*] Repetitive dungeon design
    [*] Lore is all over the place
    [*] Unable to purchase CERA on Steam
    [*] Forced to see toxic community wars in world chat at least once a day
[/list]


[u] tl;dr:[/u] I enjoy this MMO a lot and believe you should play through NeoPle's website instead of Steam for now.

47331412.review:
I'll start with the good aspects of the game. I played for a while on the jumping servers which were part of an event to help new, returning, and current players get a level 90 character in full high tier gear within just a few hours.

The gameplay itself is extremely fun, the classes feel like most of them flow really well, and it's just really satisfying to shred the enemies over and over. Even at high level, if you have a group of friends, or even just party up with random people, the bosses are difficult, but more or less fair.

The crafting system is interesting, has a lot of options even with only a few professions to choose from and all in all, it's pretty neat.

Now onto why I would never recommend the game to anyone.

Once you reach a real server you're subject to a trade lock that hinges on three major things. The completion of 2 quests, one of which is easy and can be done in 5 minutes if you have a group. The other however requires you to run 3 raids.

Raids in this game are annoying. You can only run them twice per week, and the quest that's part of removing the trade lock on your account requires you to essentially stop playing for a week to run them a third time

And then there's apparently a 1 month long wait even after you've completed the quests in order to have the trade lock removed.

Now you may be thinking. "Trade lock? that's not so bad, I'll just play by myself. I didn't plan on trading with people anyway." and that's where you'd be wrong. because this so called trade lock doesn't just affect trading, but also selling, discarding, or grinding items of a certain rarity for crafting materials and the very item you need in order to use most of your worthwhile abilities later on. Clear cubes.

If you were playing on a jumping server like I was, you'll be shunted to a real server at level 90 with your full set of epic level raiding gear and your feeling of accomplishment, and likely an inventory full of gear that you didn't realize needed to be discarded before you moved your character. You will also be familliar with just grinding the junk in your inventory for both currency for gear repairs as well as the materials you need and to make room.

The problem is, if you played on a jumping server. There was no hint that these trade locks were a thing, and all that purple rarity and higher gear cluttering your inventory that you thought you'd just clear out later is now stuck. Like I said, you can't sell it to a vendor, you can't grind it, and you can't even just drag it from your inventory and discard it.

In addition, when you leave the jump server you are given 1000 clear cubes, which sounds like a lot until you notice that your abilities require them. spending 5 here, 10 there, so on, and so forth, you might wind up using as much as a hundred or more per dungeon run. and as you can't actually grind most of the stuff in your inventory for more.

on regular servers you'll occasionally get some gear you can grind, but it's rarely more than 1 or 200 worth, which MIGHT get you through a dungeon or not. but at level 90, most of the stuff you're going to get is going to be at least purple rarity, so have fun looking at this stuff that would ordinarily be useful for crafting and just ignoring it.

So, all in all, it's a great game run by a company that took measures so extreme to try [and fail] to stop bots that it makes the game virtually unplayable for new players.

ALMOST 2 YEARS LATER UPDATE:

So, I reinstalled the game to see if I could do literally anything about the trade lock. I'm still entirely out of clear cubes, I've tried running low level content for gear I can grind but the only things that are dropping are crafting materials.

I tried contacting support with a ticket to see if they can MAYBE do something to help. Their response was to do the quest that caused me to quit in the first place. The quest that I don't have the clear cubes to do, the quest that you're not going to find a group to help you with, the quest that will take you literal weeks of waiting in order to do.

So, almost 2 years later still, **** this game.



2 hour later update: After pressing the matter the trade restriction has finally been removed. So it seems that if you're under a long time trade lock and you press them hard enough, they might MAYBE remove your trade lock.

Still, the trade lock is BS, and if you don't have the time to sink in to get it removed, don't bother with the game.

47279194.review:
I really love this game, and I'd recommend it to anyone who simply wants to have some classic arcade brawler akin to classics such as D&D Shadow over mystara, knights of the round, cadillacs and dinosours, golden axe etc.
It is arguably the best in it's genre, making one spend many hours with various characters until you get comfortable with the play style you like best. And even then, you might want to play with a character that is the polar oposite of how you normally play, just to experience the challenge.

If you can remember, my original review actually dissed Neople heavily for the amount of hoops one needed to jump through just to be able to support Neople.
It was ridiculous to the extreme, the requirements that you needed to meet just in order to be able to Purchase Cera AND use it in the store.
For your information I absolutely refused to do what I found was an equivalent of ten knuckle push ups (Anton Raid) just so I can spend money on them.

It has changed to an upvote because despite the amount of time I had to spend fighting Neople support just to throw money at them, they actually pulled through and found a way for me to use my steam wallet to purchase CERA.
This obvouisly came about by meeting them halfway, otherwise it seems Neople really struggles to get around their "policies" just so you can spend cash on them.

So how did I meet them halfway?
Firstly as you can see by hours put in, I've been playing quite a while now, so I mentioned this in the support ticket for good measure. I don't know how long you should be playing at minimum, but I figured I've been playing long enough.
I added Google Authentication.
I added a region lock.
I added the goblin pin.
I even completed Seria Support Quest 1, which was the "ten push ups" I mentioned in my orignal review.

Neople made me wait for quite a while, but they eventually met me the other halfway and made it so I can use my steam wallet to purchase Cera.
I would advise excersing patience (which I don't have, naturally) when dealing with Neople support, they eventually do get back to you...and even with an apology if they kept you waiting for a while.

Anyway, I'm just glad that after all those hoops, I finally got what I wanted even if it was the long way around.

45479086.review:
DFO is so fun!!
The combat is delicious for a side scroller game and flashy too.

 As the title says, this a dungeon based game. You go from hub to hub getting quests then doing the associated dungeon. It's still really fun and can only get boring if you've been playing 3 days without rest. 
There is fatigue in this game but i saw no issue with it and you can buy fatigue restoring things from the marketplace.

There is characters instead of char creation. Each class is gender and race locked but there is a male and female version of almost every class. The classes can also upgrade, giving them a different playstyle. I recommend testing all before making your decision because with dungeon based games, it's less of the power of a class and more about how much you enjoy it.
I honestly found myself having two male mages (#bestclass) because i loved two of the three advancements so much.

I believe every class is fairly even, with no 1 class being WAY op.

The graphics are quite nice for a sprite pixel-y game.
Looks somewhat like Mortal Combat or one of those old games like that with the numbers.

Probably runs well on a potato pc, so don't worry. NASA doesn't have to lend you one of their computers in order for you to run this game well.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys dungeon based games or just cute characters.

44812480.review:
At first I had a ridiculously frustrating negative experience with the Steam Client.

I downloaded the game, and as soon as I created my account, it was locked due to "suspicious activity". It seems that closing the game launcher and the Steam client caused some kind of fuss and flagged my IP. According to many people, the Steam Client has a lot of issues, so if you want to try the game, might as well download the Stand alone client, which is what I did. I logged in probably more than 80-90 hours.

I played for around a month or so and I had a blast. I stopped playing because none of my friends were playing the game and well, as such, I tend to get bored after that.

Anyways. There are a lot of classes to play with, and some offers quite an interresting playstyle. If you're into beat them up games and action RPG, it's worth a try, even if the game itself is quite old. Don't let you get influenced by the Stamina/Energy system: Except in the earlier levels where you can run out of energy pretty fast, it's not that important. If you really want to play, you can create another character and keep doing so.

Unless you want to be strong faster than you should, or unless you want every cosmetic item there is, you're not forced to pay and except in rare cases (maybe PvP, but I didn't try), it won't even matter if you do or don't. I was able to be raid ready in a matter of weeks, which is seriously fine.

Give it a try. You'll see right away if it's your kind of game.

44399162.review:
I reviewed this game after playing for 150 hours

The game is set in the mythical kingdom of Arad, where the once docile monsters that inhabited the kingdom have suddenly become violent. It’s up to the hero, a.k.a. the player, to protect the citizens, eliminate the root of the problem, and bring back peace to the kingdom.

DFO features persistent worlds with instanced dungeons and is one of the first MMORPGs to do so. This was then followed by Dragon Nest, Lunia, and Vindictus. Everything about this game feels retro, which might not appeal to some players. The game features retro-arcade style graphics reminiscent of old side-scrolling beat ‘em up arcade games from the SNES and SEGA Genesis era. The sound also has a classical RPG feel to it and fits the overall theme of the game quite nicely. The game has over 400 million registered users, so they must be doing something right.

DFO offers players a mix of beat ‘em up action with classical MMORPG elements, and like typical MMORPGs, quests are the player’s main source of money, equipment, and experience points. Quests can be acquired from NPCs in town and come in the form of dungeon-runs that players must successfully complete to the end. Like classic beat ‘em ups, players must first eliminate all enemies in a zone before they can proceed to the next one, usually culminating in a boss fight. Aside from the quest rewards, players can also loot items from mobs and bosses. Basically, the whole game involves visiting an NPC to start a quest, hitting the dungeon, then returning to the quest-giver to collect rewards. Rinse and repeat. This tends to get boring after a while. Good thing that the bosses pose a bit of a challenge and will definitely keep players occupied, even if it’s just for a few hours. The dungeons will seem a bit easy at first, but once you start hitting level 16+ dungeons, you’ll know what frustration is. Some bosses literally take hours to take down, and it’s not uncommon to be close to dying after just one hit. Fortunately, the game allows players to team up with four other players to complete a certain dungeon. Not sure if the game difficulty increases, since I’m more of a solo guy.

Combat and movement in DFO uses the arrow keys to move around and keyboard keys to launch attacks and trigger abilities or items in the hotbar. The game is set up so that players can easily swap their keyboards for a gamepad or even an arcade controller. I definitely recommend using a gamepad instead, simply because they’re a lot less awkward to use than keyboards for these kind of games. Anyone who's ever appreciated classic arcade beat'em ups like Double Dragon or Golden Axe will love the retro-graphics and action-oriented gameplay in Dungeon Fighter Online.

Being an MMORPG, DFO also features PvP options that players have come to expect from other MMORPGs. To access the PvP channel, players must be Level 35 and above. To even out the playing field, player stats are automatically balanced once they enter a PvP Game Room. Depending on the type of game mode selected, a typical PvP match requires at least 2 players to compete (up to a maximum of 8 players). DFO offers 5 arena-style game modes: Brawl, Deathmatch, Team, Team Deathmatch, and Elimination. Brawls are free-for-all matches where the last man standing wins. Deathmatch is similar to Brawl matches, but players are given two lives to work with. Team matches pit one team against another using Brawl match rules. Team Deathmatches features the same rules as Team matches but gives players a set number of lives to be shared by all members of the team. Lastly, Elimination matches have two teams going up against each other in one-on-one matches, where the winner of the match moves on to fight the next player of the opposing team. The last team standing wins the match.
Joining PvP matches rewards players with PvP experience, which determines their rankings on the leaderboard. Losers don’t gain any experience. Players also gain Victory Points, regardless of whether they win or lose. These Victory Points can be used to purchase special potions and high quality weapons.

Like all free-to-play MMOs, DFO features a premium item shop that lets players purchase items using Cera, which can be bought using real money. The game is still in its early stages under Neople and so far, the premium shop contains the usual fanfare of items, but nothing game-breaking. Let’s just hope that Neople doesn’t get all greedy and start implementing OP premium weapons in the future.
